SPEECH.PARA: My own experience, travelling very extensively around Australia, talking to young people and visiting young people in the circumstances that Senator Wheelwright refers to, is that those people would be in an absolute minority, if they exist at all, and I suspect they do. Certainly, young people leave homes that are divided, homes where there is abuse and alcohol, and all of the other tragedies that occur in many Australian homes.

I think the policy that Mr Howard released last year, and during the election campaign, addresses a number of concerns identified by the House of Representatives committee on youth homelessness. One of the concerns was about ensuring that there was some income support early in the program. Many of the people I spoke to—both in the voluntary sector and the young people themselves—raised this matter of not being able to get any income support for many weeks, and how that created its own problems. In many respects, it saw young people turning to prostitution and to other ways of earning an income that no‐one in this society would want to see occur.

Senator Wheelwright said he would be referring these matters to that task force and I encourage him to do so. I think it offers a positive step forward in making sure that our policy in relation to youth homelessness is more effective than what we have had in the past. I think it is a genuine attempt on the part of the Prime Minister and the coalition to address some of those problems. I think the more input comes from the community, and from interested members of parliament, and the more these matters are debated publicly, the better it will be for young Australians.

As Senator Wheelwright says, it is all very well for us to be talking about high levels of growth and low inflation, and for us to live comfortably, and have our first class cabins in aircrafts and our comfortable offices here, when only a few miles from this building, and in the hearts of most of our very successful looking capital cities, we can see that the problems of young Australians are not far below the surface. We all have a responsibility to do the best we can.

I now turn to the matter that I rose to speak on, and that is to respond to an article in today's edition of the New Scientist magazine, and a very similar article in the Herald‐Sun at page 31. The New Scientist article—I am quite happy to table it if that is required—under the headline `US ship comes to the rescue of Russian polar team', in about the fourth paragraph, refers to Australia's lack of assistance to some Russian Antarctic expeditioners, particularly at the Mirny Station, which is in Australian Antarctic territory. Basically, because of the breakdown of their supply ship, the Akademik Federov, and its having to return to Buenos Aires a few months ago, the expeditioners had to seek information from Australia on the availability of Australia's Antarctic vessel, the Aurora Australis. They wanted to know whether the ship was available for charter to assist in providing very important supplies of food and other items to the wintering party of approximately 38 expeditioners from the Russian Antarctic service who will have to winter at the Russian base at Mirny.
The misleading part of the article in the New Scientist magazine—also the misleading part of the article in the Herald‐Sun, which was a virtual copy—says:

Russian officials had first turned to Australia for help. They wanted to charter Aurora Australis, an Australian research vessel and icebreaker, to clear a path through the ice to allow the Akademik Federov to reach Mirny more quickly.
The article goes on to say:

But negotiations with the Australians are thought to have broken down because the Russian govern ment would not pay for the charter in advance. Rex Moncur, director of the Australian Antarctic Division, declined to comment on discussions between the two countries.

At the outset, can I say that Mr Moncur, who is the head of the Australian Antarctic Division and an exceptional Australian and exceptional servant of the government of Australia in his role as the Antarctic Division chief, was quite right not to divulge to any journalist the discussions that took place between Australia, Russia and other nations in relation to this expedition. Those matters were, of course, confidential. I want to set out the facts for the record and for the benefit of a Mr Vincent Kiernan, whose by‐line is on the New Scientist magazine article, and Kristin Owen, the so‐called science reporter of the Herald‐Sun .

When I and my staff and the head of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories were in Hobart on 24 May, Rex Moncur advised us that a request had indeed come from the Russian Antarctic expedition to find out whether or not Aurora Australis would be available for charter for a mission to assist them in ensuring that their wintering party at the Mirny base could be restocked for the winter. Can I say that, entirely contrary to the articles that I refer to, the Australian Antarctic Division, with the close involvement of myself as the parliamentary secretary with responsibility for this division, ensured that within hours—it is fair to say—the Russians knew that the Aurora Australis would be available. In fact on 25 May, less than 24 hours after the official sending of a request from the Russians, it was made quite clear to them that the Australians would be available to assist.

The articles then refer to what has occurred subsequently and the success of a mission that involved the United States experimental ship Nathaniel B. Palmer which was able to give some interim supplies to the Mirny base on 12 June. The Australian Antarctic Division and the Russian Antarctic division communicated virtually on an hourly basis on these matters from about 24 May—and the matters are still being discussed and communicated on. Part of those discussions was that Australia was quite successful, through our Antarctic division, in negotiating between the United States and the Russians—not that that was required in any diplomatic sense. It was purely, in a logistic and communications sense, a matter of informing the United States of the situation at the Russian base, informing the Russians of the proximity of the US vessel to the Russian base, communicating information about ice conditions, weather conditions, the steaming time it would take the United States ship to get to Mirny and whether that was possible, and keeping up to date on the requirement of the Australian vessel.

This engagement by the Australian Antarctic Division, and our ready communication to them that the Aurora Australis would be made available, is absolutely contradictory to what has been stated in the Herald‐Sun and the New Scientist magazine. There were no negotiation breakdowns. The negotiations were not even negotiations. It was simply a question of: `Is the boat available for charter?' And the Australian response was: `Yes, it is.' So that is contrary to the article. I will refer to two documents that were part of those massive communications between Russia and Australia on this issue. I will quote from an E‐mail of 17 June directed to the Australian division. It is from the Russians and it reports on the success of the United States ship in supplying some tonnes of food to the Mirny station. It says, in conclusion:

The success was achieved due to the international cooperation in the Antarctic Treaty spirit. Many thanks to you and your colleagues for being so much involved in our problems. We also will be glad to help you if ever needed. Sincerely,
Valery Lukin.

Another cable was received in relation to this matter, dated 31 May. I say this just to inform the Senate and particularly to inform those journalists who seek to write stories without even communicating with me or with the people at the Antarctic Division. This cable is a foreign affairs statement coming from the head, Arctic and Antarctic and Sea Administration, Federal Service for Hydrometeorology and Monitoring of the Environment, from Russia. It reads:

The Arctic and Antarctic and Sea Administration of the Federal Service for Hydrometeorology and Monitoring of the Environment expresses its great appreciation for the attention of (the Australian Government) to the problems which have arisen in relation to the operations of the regular 41st Russian Antarctic expedition.
It goes on to say:

The Russian Antarctic expedition acknowledges the receipt of information about the conditions for leasing the Australian icebreaker ship, Aurora Australis. We are currently studying this information. In the event of the need to request the use of this ship we will inform you.
Please accept our gratitude for your assistance, with sincere respect and best wishes, V A Martyshchenko.

I conclude, Madam Acting Deputy President, by saying that the operations of nations such as Russia, the United States, Australia, New Zealand and the other Antarctic nations in what is one of the most hostile environments—perhaps the most hostile environment—on this globe require a commitment to the ideals of the nations that go to Antarctica to conduct science and research. They require a level of international cooperation which is not demonstrated in many other parts of the globe. The sort of cooperation that occurred in this venture that the Australian government has been involved in is a demonstration of the sort of cooperation that is required in Antarctica. It is one of the great frontiers, if not the last great frontier.

Regardless of the improvement in technology in terms of the ships, the aircraft that can get down to the Antarctic territories and the communications facilities, the weather conditions at Antarctica and the adjoining Southern Ocean are absolutely abysmal. They offer an incredible challenge to any man or woman who decides to venture down there. Those things have not changed since the time that Douglas Mawson set off down there.

I take this opportunity to say to Rex Moncur, the head of the Antarctic Division, to Jack Sayers, who handled much of the communication with his Russian counterparts, and to the Americans, who have also cooperated in this venture, that they all deserve to be congratulated by all Australian citizens and those who are wintering in Antarctica at the moment. We wish the Russian ship, the Akademik Fedorov, the very best of luck, because it will require much of that, in its final attempt to get to Mirny Station. It is far from certain that it will be able to get there; but, thanks to the Nathaniel Palmer's going in there, putting some interim supplies into the Mirny Station and having put a trail through the ice, that should make it a bit easier for the Akademik Fedorov. But we do wish them good luck. The Russians at Mirny Station and the crew of the Akademik Fedorov take with them the best wishes of the Australian Antarctic Division and, I am quite sure, of all members and senators and the people of Australia in what is a very challenging voyage for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for his question.
