ANSWER.PARA: Basically, her question comes in three parts. She asked me to agree that economic rationalism has dominated the debate over the last decade. She asked me whether I have read something about someone she identifies as a guru of downsizing, who is now prepared to do a mea culpa and say that he got it wrong. And she asked me whether I have seen a particular piece of United States research and, subsequently, whether I have raised that with my colleagues in discussions about necessary downsizing.

In relation to each of those questions, of course economic rationalism has played a very significant part in the debate over the last decade. I see no value in answering that any other way. The battle of ideas is what politics is about. Of course it has played a significant part, as have other arguments—the contrary arguments, in fact. Anyone interested in politics would tell you that, when you raise an argument or propose a particular theory or particular approach to matters, you necessarily draw out those who would want to go the other way. So the answer to that is that perhaps it has not been the most dominant but it has undoubtedly been a dominant player in the battle of ideas over the last decade.

As to the guru who once promoted downsizing and now does not, there must be dozens of people over the world who have a view one day and another the next. So I do not choose to respond to that other than to say that, if that is the case, so what. Plenty of people change their minds on a whole range of things. As to the particular United States research, I do not know that I have seen it. I would be happy for Senator Kernot to forward it to my office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, it is not a matter of just dismissing it. Sometimes ideas are wrong and sometimes the theories that people are locked into are wrong. Do you agree with the assessment by former Treasury forecaster Chris Murphy that your $8 billion budget cuts will cost 50,000 jobs in the economy as a whole over the next year? Would you agree with the Age newspaper editorial that there is a limit which may have been exceeded by the nation as a whole which picks up the bill for high unemployment in dole payments, health services, prisons and youth suicides? Are you factoring this into your budget considerations, or are you going to continue to follow the failed theories of the past?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has no intention of following what Senator Kernot chooses to identify as failed theories of the past. The government certainly does not want to run its agenda, economic or otherwise, on the basis of what it reads in editorials on a day‐to‐day basis. That certainly would not be the case.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot perhaps should take this matter to heart: one thing this government will not do is hide its head in the sand, as the previous government did. We had three or more years of growth under the previous government and still running a budget deficit—spend, spend, spend! They just hid their heads in the sand and hoped that things would get better, and of course they didn't. That is why these people left office with over 700,000 people looking for work and not able to find it. Within that 700,000 there were plenty of underemployed people and more people out there who had given up—the hidden unemployed—looking for jobs. One of the best contributions we can make to providing real jobs for Australians is getting the budget back into the black. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Commonwealth Bank of Australia: Share Offer

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Is the minister aware of comments by Mr John Valder, the former Chairman of the Sydney Stock Exchange, that the terms of the proposed $4 billion Commonwealth Bank of Australia sale are `highway robbery', `bushranger stuff' and that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia is `conning ordinary people'? Further, is the minister aware that Mr Valder has said that the Australian Securities Commission should have brought the matter to the attention of the Department of Finance? Will the minister give the government's version of these events and disprove Mr Valder's claims?

—I think I have the pleasure of receiving Senator Jones's last question in this place. If so, I thank him for it. So far as the question is concerned, both the government and I are aware of the comments from Mr Valder, the former Chairman of the Sydney Stock Exchange. In response to his comments I make the following response: I frequently agree with Mr Valder, but on this occasion I certainly do not. Far from small shareholders being disadvantaged under the Commonwealth's share offer, the two-tiered process will in fact enable a more accurate price for the shares to be determined.

PARA.BREAK: In that regard, the offer document clearly indicates to prospective investors the process involved for determining the ultimate share price. That price is set following an open bidding process by institutional investors. Although the ASC has looked at drafts of the offer document, the document itself clearly states that the Commonwealth is not bound by the prospectus requirements of the Corpora tions Law. So the response to the question in summary is that, yes, I am aware of the comments of Mr Valder and I do not, nor does the government, agree with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does that answer from Senator Short mean that he disagrees with Mr Valder and that he does not really know what he is talking about?

—What it means is that Mr Valder has—and I am glad he has—a particular view on a particular subject. Others have particular views on particular subjects. We do not always agree, and on this occasion we do not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, given your press release of 15 May 1996, which stated that expansion plans for uranium mining would be assessed under the `strictest environmental and heritage guidelines', what environmental conditions were attached to the approval of orebody 3 at the Ranger mine in the world heritage region of Kakadu National Park? Can you provide the details of the water management plan and tailings management arrangements to cater for the expansion of mining at orebody 3? If, as we believe, there is not either, why wasn't a new EIS and water management plan developed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that the area known as the Ranger lease, which includes orebody 3 and orebody 1, is not part of the Kakadu National Park, nor is it in a world heritage area. The environmental conditions associated with both orebody 1, which is now mined out, and orebody 3, which is about to be mined, are as follows: conditions specified in the Northern Territory Uranium Mining (Environmental Control) Act 1981; conditions and standards specified in the general authorisation to mine approved by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy; and conditions required by the Commonwealth government as described in the environmental requirements which are attached to the Atomic Energy Act 1953 and the Northern Territory Uranium Mining (Environmental Control) Act 1981.

ANSWER.PARA: The application from ERA Ltd to develop orebody 3 was submitted to the Northern Territory minister for mines, as required under the UM(EC) Act. As required under the working arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments, the application was forwarded to the OSS for technical comment. The Northern Territory minister is required to take prime regard of advice from the OSS. This procedure was followed in respect of the orebody 3 application.

Orebody 3 is similar in many characteristics to orebody 1, including size, grade, proximity to the Ranger mill and geological characteristics. The Office of the Supervising Scientist has advised me that mining orebody 1 has proceeded for 16 years without significant environmental impact. I anticipate a similar good result of environmental management during the mining of orebody 3 by application of the same environmental conditions.

In relation to the second question, ERA has recently revised the Ranger five-year water management plan. This plan is to be assessed by stakeholders at the Alligator Rivers region advisory committee meeting on 5 July and by the environmental performance review to be conducted by the OSS and the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy on 1 July. Outcomes of these assessments will be put on the public record.

Tailings arising from the mining of orebody 3 are to be deposited in the orebody 1 pit. This disposal method has been developed following consultations between the OSS, the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy and ERA. I am advised that it will be an effective way of disposal in both the short and long term and that the environmental and health risks will be minimised.

The government, through the OSS, is in constant contact with ERA Ltd and the Northern Territory government authorities over the issue of environmental protection at Ranger through technical working groups and twice yearly environmental audits. Results of this work are made public by processes managed by the OSS. It is my view that these ongoing systems have a proven record of delivering high quality environmental outcomes and that the environmental conditions and level of supervision at Ranger provide a level of protection at least as good as the EIS process.

The original approvals for mining in the area known as the Ranger lease included an exemption from the provisions of the EP(IP) Act 1974. This was, of course, because the terms and conditions for mining were settled under Mr Justice Fox's inquiry and that mining has proceeded subsequently pursuant to those terms and conditions. Commonwealth processes for environmental protection at Ranger have been in place for 20 years. I reiterate my commitment to strictest environmental and heritage guidelines for expansion of the uranium industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that the last EIS conducted for Ranger was nearly 20 years ago and that many environmental concerns have been raised about the operation of the Ranger mine, how can the minister justify the inconsistency between exempting orebody 3 from the administrative requirements of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and his promise to apply the strictest environmental conditions to the plan to expand uranium mining in this country? Minister, in relation to what I said about the world heritage region, we all know that excising a mine from a world heritage park does not mean it is not in a world heritage region.

—I thought I answered the question. Both orebody 1 and orebody 3 are within the area known as the Ranger lease, which was the subject of the inquiry under Mr Justice Fox. The terms and conditions for mining in the Ranger lease were determined at that time and have been subjected to the most rigorous of ongoing assessment by not only Commonwealth authorities but also the authorities of the Northern Territory government. There has been a constant process of public consultation since to ensure that there is public confidence in the process that has been undertaken. Basically, the assessments have indicated a very good environmental record, and I have every reason to believe that that will continue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wheelwright, Sen Thomas

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer—and I would ask him not to make any assumptions about me until midnight next Sunday; I will keep punching until I hear the bell ring. Minister, I refer you to your statement in question time on Monday, where you said:

QUESTION.PARA: Publishing updated forecasts is not only good in terms of fostering fiscal responsibility; it is good for democracy all round.

Minister, in the interests of democracy, will you immediately publish all the details of the April round of the Joint Economic Forecasting Group as indicated by the National Commission of Audit? Will you also agree that by publishing this material you would avoid the accusation of publishing only those forecasts which suit your political purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —What we as a government have said—this is something that the former government, a Labor government, steadfastly refused to do through its 13 years in office—is that we will introduce a charter of budget honesty, which we will do. We announced a year ago that we would introduce this, and we will do so at an early appropriate opportunity.

ANSWER.PARA: This will, amongst other things, keep governments honest in the run-up to elections by requiring governments to publish forecasts and available information when an election is announced and in the run-up to an election. We will also have much more expanded information in terms of the mid-year reviews. In other words, we will be a transparent government. We will be a government that will tell the Australian people before they have to choose their government what the state of the nation's finances are like.

PARA.BREAK: In that way we will not be seeking to deceive the Australian people, as your government did in the lead-up to the last election by refusing point blank, despite the fact that you had all the information, to reveal the figures about the true state of this nation's finances—a state which, as we all know, was a disaster. This has caused great hardship to the Austral ian people. Unless this is rectified through the budget and in other responsible economic policy ways, it will perpetuate the poverty and the disaster that Labor wreaked on so many Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: We are not going to do that, Senator Wheelwright. We are going to be very transparent in carrying out our responsibility to be honest with the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't the National Commission of Audit say that `the commission considers it would be unwise to require the release of such reports', as you indicated, at election time `only if economic conditions had changed significantly since the release of the last outlook report'? Isn't that surely the case with the national accounts for the March quarter? Isn't there a JEFG round going on right now? Aren't you obliged to either release the April round or release the one now? You have to release one of them, according to your own National Commission of Audit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —So far as the National Commission of Audit is concerned, it was an independent commission, as you know. It is a report to the government; it is not a report by the government. It makes a lot of very important and thought‐provoking suggestions and recommendations particularly, as Senator Wheelwright knows, in the area of financial reporting and financial accounting.

ANSWER.PARA: I would have thought that Senator Wheelwright, with his background, would welcome the statements in the Commission of Audit report about the need for greater transparency and fullness in government financial reporting. That is what it recommends. We will have a look at the particular recommendations it has made. We have our own ideas about them and we will in due course produce results which will take full account of all the various views expressed, including, but not exclusively, those made by the Commission of Audit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. The National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling has reported that under Labor in May 1995 almost two million Australians were living in poverty. Earlier this month UNICEF released a report showing that Australia is one of only five industrialised nations to have more than 10 per cent of its children living in poverty. How has this shocking number of poor and needy in our country been permitted to come about? What does this say about the previous Labor government's record on social justice and its social and economic policies? What commitments has the government provided on the social security safety net?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting, isn't it, that we have a Labor opposition now which seems to have discovered the poor and needy once it has come into opposition. It did not seem to notice them too much in the 13 years it was creating them. It is true that after 13 years of a Labor government Australia has one of the most unfair distributions of national income in the developed world. There has been a 3.9 per cent decline in average real household income between 1981-82 and 1993-94. During the same period there has been a 5.7 per cent increase in inequality.

ANSWER.PARA: Even the claims that we get constantly from the Labor Party that somehow the social wage has compensated for greater income inequality have been exposed as untrue. The recent ABS study proved that the transfer payments, which are the social wage, have not fully offset the growing inequality. Under Labor—they do not want to hear this and they do not want the people outside to hear this—the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't like to hear it, do you. The National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling report that Senator Chapman referred to reported that 11.8 per cent of Australians—some 1.7 million people, including half a million of Australia's children—were living below the Henderson poverty line in May last year; during the opposition's time in government. The evidence is overwhelming. That is the number and proportion of people living in poverty after 13 years of your stewardship.

PARA.BREAK: Senator Chapman mentioned the UNICEF report on Australian children living in fami lies with inadequate income. Australia is one of only five industrialised nations to have more than 10 per cent of its children living in poverty. Shame on you! You can make a lot of noise like a rabble, but do you really care about our kids? Do you remember the great promise about the children living in poverty? You can make a noise now.

ANSWER.PARA: We not only have more income inequality than when you came to government in 1983 but also have many more people who need to resort to social security assistance. In June 1983 there were 1.5 million Australians of work force age receiving payments, excluding family payments. As at March 1994 there were 2.3 million Australians in that position.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Newman has the call.
—You should be ashamed of yourselves. You are great on the rhetoric of social justice and you are great on egalitarianism, but when it comes to the facts you do not—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not going to erode the safety net. We have given promises that that will underpin our social security system. We will maintain the real value of pensions and other social security benefits. We will not force people with disabilities onto unemployment benefits. We will not place a time limit on the receipt of unemployment benefits and we will maintain existing sole parent pension arrangements. We will not force workers off awards. We will not introduce a $3 a week youth wage. We will retain Medicare. We will retain bulk-billing and community rating for private health insurance. No matter how much noise comes from the other side, the Australian people know who the guilty party is, and there is no getting away from it.

—My question is directed to the Minster for Communications and the Arts. The minister would be aware that at last night's hearing of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Reference Committee, Labor Senators Carr, Schacht and Wheelwright trotted out the same tired old claims that Telstra actually performs well compared to telecommunications companies in other countries when Australia's low population density and long distances are taken into account. Would you, minister, please enlighten the Senate as to whether Telstra itself has acknowledged that these claims are not true, and that Telstra needs to improve its performance relative to that achieved by other telecommunications companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hear reports of the performance of the tragic troika. It is very sad that the best that Labor could put together is a union hack, a failed primary school teacher and a party functionary and ministerial hanger-on, someone who has just told us he is going to have to find a real job shortly. What they did last night was trot out an excuse that Telstra itself abandoned some years ago. In other words, for many years those who would defend the public sector monopoly of Telstra used to argue that somehow we were different from the rest of the world because we had a very large country, a very low level of population and therefore there was something special about it. Even Senator Collins trots that line out from time to time in here.

ANSWER.PARA: So it is particularly significant, I think, that when Mr Blunt last week made it perfectly clear where the corporation stood in relation to privatisation, he also said what he has said many times before, and that is that our most recent studies show that we are still about 30 per cent off world's best practice as measured by operating expenses per access line. We have to assume that our competitors will be at or near the benchmark level, so we have to attain that level too. How more frequently can you say it and in what plainer terms than that?

PARA.BREAK: The fact is that the company itself acknowledges that this is no longer a basis for defending the indefensible. Indeed, when I went with Mr Blunt to talk to some 1,200 Telstra employees in Sydney a few months ago, Mr Blunt gave them that precise message and they accepted it overwhelmingly. They ac knowledged the need for change. They acknowledged the need for the company to lift its game. I know that people like Senator Faulkner, who treat this place with contempt, particularly on certain occasions when they think it is more important to parade and make sure that their colleagues are not talking behind their backs, are not interested in this because they are captives of the trade union movement. But the fact is that Telstra can do a lot better than it does at present.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot pretends that downsizing is something that one needs to get hysterical about in defending Telstra when, as Senator Vanstone pointed out, between 1990 and 1994, when Telstra downsized to the tune of about 25,000 employees purely by voluntary redundancies and redeployment, there was not a squawk from those who now confect anger on the subject.

Once again, what we have on the Labor side is people not prepared to face up to the real issues. If you want some real entertainment, you ought to go along to some of these business lunches where people like Kim Beazley have to defend the indefensible. I can assure you that he squirms, just as do his other front bench colleagues.

Indeed, I was told the other day of a discussion between a leading Australian businessman and former Senator McMullan, currently with the responsibility for industrial relations. When asked, `Why on earth does the outfit that privatised everything that moves now have an objection to privatising Telstra?', the best he could trot out was, `Well, we do not believe in partial privatisation.' It is pathetic.

I simply urge the likes of Senator Schacht, when they are swanning off around the world during the recess, to take some time out, go over to your socialist colleagues in Cuba and Albania, explain to them why we are out of step, ask them why they have lost the faith, why they have a different view of the world to yours. It might be about time that you faced up to the reality that you are going to be the ones responsible for Telstra having a second-class future. If that is what you want to see, then I can assure you that you are not friends of Telstra. You are simply the people who are going to make yourselves more and more embarrassed during the course of this inquiry, and it is what you deserve. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, would you please provide to the Senate as evidence some of the contrasts between the performance of Telstra and similar telecommunication companies that are operating throughout the world under similar circumstances to Telstra in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The most normal international measure is access lines per employee. Telstra has about 140 compared to US West, which happens to cover 14 states of the US very similar in geographic dispersity. They have about 280 lines per employee. Some of the OECD statistics are just as enlightening. According to the Bureau of Industry Economics in its latest report of March this year, when it came to business fixed charges, Australia ranked 18 out of 28; long distance call charges 16 out of 26; international call charges 14 out of 24; packet switch data networks 18 out of 24; a national basket of prices, 14 out of 23. I think I have already recited this litany on earlier occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that Telstra needs to lift its game in many respects. You might like to have virtually the highest local call charges in the world, you might like Australia to be about fifth in terms of rental charges, you might like Australia to be, as Frank Blunt says, 30 per cent off the pace in terms of operating costs per employee, but we don't and we won't. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait lslander Affairs. Minister, in parliament yesterday I asked you how many potential conflict of interest situations had been identified by KPMG and reported to ATSIC so far. You said you were unable to say, the reason being that `the numbers were difficult to obtain.' Is it not a fact that the instructions manual issued by ATSIC on behalf of the special auditor says this:

QUESTION.PARA: KPMG have identified a number of organisations where conflict of interest occurs.
Minister, if the instruction manual widely distributed to ATSIC regional officers clearly states that your special auditor has already identified a number of these, why can't you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for the question. He was quite correct: yesterday I did not have those figures. I am happy to give him the answer today, and I intend tabling the information at the end of question time.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said yesterday, in line with normal practice for contracts with the Commonwealth, the contract with KPMG to undertake the tasks of the special auditor contains provisions on how potential conflicts of interest are to be handled. The contract provides for substituted performance of the special auditor tasks for those indigenous organisations with which KPMG currently have a commercial relationship. The firm of Pannell Kerr Forster, or its national affiliates, will be used by KPMG to undertake the task of special auditor where there is a potential conflict of interest for KPMG.

KPMG has advised the Commonwealth that there are approximately 60 indigenous organisations with which they have a commercial relationship of the 2,000 or so organisations which are likely to be scrutinised in the special auditor process. The contract also provides a notification and consent procedure for any further potential conflicts of interest which may arise during the contract period.

The conflict of interest arrangements were part of the original tender assessment. These are standard mechanisms for dealing with potential conflicts of interest and I would be surprised if anyone had any problems with that. Indeed, I would have expected severe criticism if the Commonwealth did not put conflict of interest mechanisms such as these in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to reports today to the death of honorary consul James Nichols in a prison in Rangoon and the failure of the SLORC to release Mr Nichols' body to his family. I ask the minister: does the Australian government support the call by Amnesty International for a full investigation into the circumstances surrounding Mr Nichols' death; will the government formally seek an explanation from the SLORC about Mr Nichols' death; and, finally, will the Australian government follow the lead of the United States and call on the SLORC to release all those prisoners in Burma who are being detained solely because of their political beliefs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Dealing with the third part of the question first, I inform the Senate that the Australian government remains concerned about the human rights situation in Burma. The government has repeatedly and strongly urged the government of Burma to improve its human rights record, including by releasing all those detained for the peaceful expression of their political beliefs.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sorry to have to confirm that Leo Nichols died after suffering a stroke at Rangoon's Insein prison on 22 June. Leo Nichols was a close supporter of Aung San Suu Kyi and had a longstanding and warm relationship with the Australian embassy in Rangoon, including with successive Australian ambassadors. He was arrested in April of this year for clearly political reasons. I understand that he was charged with being in possession of an unregistered telephone for which he would suffer the maximum of three years imprisonment.

Officers from the Australian embassy in Rangoon made representations to the Burmese authorities concerning Mr Nichols' arrest. The Australian government was immediately concerned by the reports of his death. I understand that officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs have been in close contact with his family members in Australia in order to keep them informed of developments following Mr Nichols death, and that the government has offered assistance as appropriate.

I am told that the Australian authorities are not aware that there is anything to indicate that Mr Nichols' death resulted from anything other than natural causes. However, as you would know, senator, conditions in Insein gaol are notoriously bad, and Mr Nichols was an elderly man and not in the best of health. I am advised that an autopsy was performed. We expect that the autopsy results will be released to Mr Nichols' family. It would be inappropriate to comment upon such matters until the results of the autopsy are known. Our embassy in Rangoon will continue to monitor the situation closely and seek further information from the Burmese authorities when appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, did the ATSIC regional office in Derby advise the Junjuwa community in writing last night that, until your special auditor arrives there on 8 July and formally clears them, ATSIC `cannot confirm a time frame for release of CDEP wages or community infrastructure for the first quarter of 1996'? Did the regional office go on to say that they cannot advise whom they can even offer funds to, let alone make releases to? Do you agree that this confirms that you have consistently misrepresented the position of these communities in this chamber and continue to do so, and that your statement that these Aboriginal communities should not be believed is yet another disgraceful and unwarranted attack by you on Aboriginal people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned by the misinformation and scaremongering that is going on in many Aboriginal communities regarding funding and the special auditor.
—This is a letter from the ATSIC office.
—We have had yet another example today. I am advised by staff in some ATSIC regional offices that there is some mischief making—
—I will rub your nose in it in five minutes.

—Perhaps I could repeat that, Mr President, because of the sledging that is going on the other side. I am sure that the people who are listening would like to hear the answer. I am advised, Senator Collins, by staff in some ATSIC regional offices that there is some mischief making going on. I might add that the opposition has done its part to stir up confusion and mayhem, which I find highly irresponsible.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason we had to appoint a special auditor in the first place is that the previous government ignored problems of accountability and service delivery. It appears that some ATSIC regional councils are telling community groups that funding is not guaranteed over the next three months, or are in other ways misrepresenting the special auditor process.

ATSIC has been aware since 10 April of the nature of the information required to be provided by ATSIC to the special auditor, once appointed. I would like to repeat, as I have done almost every day for the past week, that organisations will continue to receive funding unless there is a serious breach of grant requirements. Even then, there are processes in place to provide interim funding where any delays might cause hardship to Aboriginal people.

On 6 June I wrote to the chairman of ATSIC, Ms Lois O'Donoghue, setting out the transitional arrangements. The transitional arrangements ensured that there will not be any delay in funding to those organisations where there is no breach of grant requirements. Funding will flow as usual.

The arrangements also minimise delays in the provision of grants to organisations whose performance to date suggests that the special auditor may not find them not fit and proper. There is no reason why grants should be frozen or communities should be missing out on service delivery.

ATSIC regional offices and the media should get their facts straight and stop whipping up a frenzy of misinformation in the communities. I suggest to Senator Collins that if he received a letter last night from a particular organisation, it would have taken a phone call to my office to resolve the information that came through. I do not understand the motivation of Senator Collins if he really has the interest of indigenous people at heart.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you aware that not one phone call but two phone calls were made to your office this morning by the Junjuwa council in a desperate effort not to close down their CDEP scheme; that they were told that `There was no‐one available to talk to them'; that one hour ago the Junjuwa council in fact terminated their CDEP scheme, sacked 210 people from that scheme; and that officers from the DSS office in Broome are travelling to the community tomorrow to fill out application forms for those people to be enrolled for unemployment benefits? `A phone call to your office'—what a joke!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, one can only assume, if those circumstances are correct, that the grant body is in serious trouble in relation to audit.
—You have no right to assume they are the facts of the matter.
—They are the facts of the matter, Mr President. If they happen to be misrepresented by Senator Collins, then so be it; it is on his head, not on mine.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

DEBATE.TITLE: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1996INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1996

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, last week—in fact on 20 June—during the debate in this chamber on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, a number of questions in relation to guns were asked by opposition senators—I think Senator Bolkus, Senator Cook and Senator Bob Collins—which I took on notice because they did not relate to my portfolio. I have obtained answers to those questions, and I now seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—
QUESTIONS TAKEN ON NOTICE IN SENATE—20 JUNE 1996
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

During debate on this bill, a number of questions asked by Opposition Senators were taken on notice. I have obtained answers to those questions and have provided them to the Opposition. I seek leave to have the answers incorporated in Hansard .
Senator BOLKUS (p1926)—In terms of the date of royal assent of the legislation, could you give us an indication when the government anticipates that the Act will come into effect?
A. The Act comes into effect on the date of Royal Assent which is expected this week. The levy increase will be effective from 1 July 1996.

Senator BOLKUS (p1926)—So you can take on notice to the Attorney-General the questions of when we should expect legislation or regulation to control the import of the weapons that are now to be banned for import and what other objectives the government intends to control in that legislation?

A. The Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations were amended on 5 June 1996 to control all importations of firearms included in the Police Ministers' agreements of 10 May 1996. The controls also allow importations in line with the various exceptions outlined in those agreements.

Senator BOLKUS (p1927)—My next set of questions were going to the timetable of implementations at the state level of state laws. The first question is: when do we anticipate those laws will be in place?—when is the scheme actually going to start?
A. On advice available to the Commonwealth the situation with State and Territory firearms laws is as follows:

PARA.TAB: A comprehensive firearms Bill has been passed by the NSW Lower House and is now before the Upper House.
In Tasmania, a new firearms bill is currently before the Parliament.
In the ACT, significant changes to legislation giving effect to the police ministers' agreements have been passed.
Victoria has put legislation relating to the extension of the prohibitions before its Parliament.
Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory are currently considering the necessary amendments and anticipate their passage by August or September.
Finally, Queensland is consulting widely on the necessary amendments to implement the police ministers' agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator BOLKUS (p1927)—There is another question I would like you to take on notice with respect to those laws. Once again, how those laws operate will determine what number of guns have to be brought back. But who is going to monitor the consistency jurisdiction as opposed to jurisdiction—for instance, Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria—and what mechanism is in place to ensure that all those laws are consistent?

A. Responsibility for monitoring the implementation of the agreements rests with the Australasian Police Ministers' Council. That body is supported by a full time Secretariat and a Senior Officers' Group. Council will meet on 3 and 4 July to review progress. Each jurisdiction has been sharing information on draft provisions as well.

Senator BOLKUS (p1927)—Is there going to be federal government involvement in the monitoring of the buyback scheme? Is it just going to be run by the states? Exemptions will be given. Who will monitor what guns will be exempt from the ban and, as a consequence, what guns will be bought back?

A. The scheme will be administered by each jurisdiction but will be consistent across Australia. The agreements of Police Ministers clearly set out those firearms subject to surrender and it is expected that each jurisdiction will keep the Police Ministers' Council informed. The Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board will monitor the scheme and advise the Attorney-General.

Senator BOLKUS (p1928)—It is going to be important, in terms of the buyback scheme, to know which interpretation of the agreement the government is going to settle on. Is it going to settle on the Queensland Government's interpretation, or is it going to settle on the interpretation that the Prime Minister has quite strenuously been putting over recent weeks—an interpretation which the opposition is fully in support of?. . . Can you give us an assurance, for instance, that it will be the Prime Minister's interpretation, when he said on Tuesday that any suggestion that people could have the centre-fire semi-automatic rifle would be clearly outside the agreement?

A. On 20 June 1996 the Prime Minister reiterated the Government's commitment to the spirit and letter of the police ministers' decision. Some proposals have been made about possible changes to that decision. The Prime Minister has stated that, unless he is satisfied that a proposal complies with the spirit of what was agreed, he will not support that proposal.

Senator BOLKUS (p1928)—. . . Can you explain to the Senate the basis for the estimate of $500 million for the buyback scheme? How have you come to that figure, on what basis and on what range of guns?

A. There is no accurate estimate of the cost of the compensation scheme because several jurisdictions do not yet have any, or any effective firearms registration system. It is the Government's belief that the levy amount of $500 million will be sufficient but the Prime Minister has given an undertaking that any residue will be refunded.

Senator BOLKUS (p1928)—On what basis was that estimate reached? is there any documentation that was available to the State Ministers. If there is such documentation can it be made available to the chamber?. . . Can we have an assurance that whatever documentation may have been available to that portfolio will be made available to us as well?

A. There is no documentation that can be provided on this issue. The Government received policy advice, in both oral and written form, and it is not appropriate to make policy advice available to the Senate.

Senator BOLKUS (p1929)—How will the weapons be valued, and by what mechanism? We anticipate, but we want reassurance here, that the value of the weapon will be fair and just compensation, as is necessary under the constitution . . . . Would they be paid the written-down value of the weapon, or would they be paid the actual current market value of the weapon?

A. The Attorney-General has received advice on the compensation for surrender scheme which he is now considering. When the Government settles the scheme the details will be made public. The Government is committed to paying fair and proper compensation.

Senator BOLKUS (p1929)—What mechanism has been contemplated to actually pay to the States the amount of money that those agents of the Commonwealth will presumably be paying to individual weapon owners? Is it anticipated: that the money will be paid in advance of the scheme's operation, so that the states have a fund from which to fund the buyback scheme, or is it going to be paid on receipt of the accounts?
A. This matter has not been settled but will be addressed once the scheme has been agreed. It is likely that the funds will be paid on receipt of accounts.

Senator BOLKUS (p1930)—. . . The Prime Minister asserted that the crimping and modification of firearms to make them circumvent the ban was something that was not acceptable to him, because the crimping was reversible . . . . Could you make available to the Senate the advice on which the Prime Minister has made his assessment? Could you make available to the Senate the advice on which the Prime Minister has made his assessment?

A. The Government has received advice on this issue from the ballistics experts of the Australian Federal Police through the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board. That advice has been both oral and written and forms part of the police advice process. It is not appropriate to make policy advice available to the Senate.

Senator BOB COLLINS (p1931)—. . . Therefore, on the basis of that information, is Senator Short, on behalf of the government, able to reject the assertions that this could be double the cost, per capita?
A. On the best advice available, the Government believes that the amount to be raised by the one‐off increase to the Medicare levy will be sufficient.

Senator BOB COLLINS (p1931)—. . . Is the government confident—on the advice currently available to it as a guesstimate—to reject the suggestion that it could be twice or even three times the estimate?
A. On the best advice available, the Government believes that the amount to be raised by the one-off increase to the Medicare levy will be sufficient.

Senator BOB COLLINS (p1931)—At the end of the day, if it is a billion dollars. . . and if this is a one-off to raise $500 million, and an additional $500 million, $700 million or $800 million is needed, how does the government intend to raise that additional revenue?
A. On the best advice available, the Government believes that the amount to be raised by the one-off increase to the Medicare levy will be sufficient.
Senator BOB COLLINS (p1932)—(People) want some assurance from the Government that you have at least a ballpark idea of how much it is going to cost them at the end of 12 months.
A. The levy is to be a one-off increase and the amount it will cost average tax payers is clear.

Senator BOB COLLINS (p1932)—What I would like to ask, Senator Short, and I am sure you can answer this, is whether in fact the fund will be used for such purposes or restricted only to the purpose of purchasing firearms.
A. The Prime Minister has announced that the funds raised from the increase in the Medicare levy will be devoted solely to the purpose of funding compensation for surrendered prohibited firearms.

Senator COOK (p1933)—Will the government supply the opposition with the basis upon which the broad calculations have been made—that is, the `back of the envelope' calculations, rather than the `to the last cent' type of calculations—as soon as it possibly can?
A. See earlier answers to Senators Bolkus and Collins.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on 19 June Senator Chamarette asked a question without notice. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the answer to that question.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE
SENATOR CHRISTABEL CHAMARETTE—19 JUNE 1996
I refer the Minister to answers by her colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs concerning Aboriginal infant mortality rates, to ask:
(1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the announcement that funding for the Ngunytju Tjitji Pirni health project in Kalgoorlie is to end at the end of 1996?
The Government is committed to supporting effective primary health care initiatives in maternal and child health care managed by community-controlled health services.
The Ngunytju Tjitji Pirni was established primarily as a research project securing the vast majority of its funds from an NHMRC Research Grant.
(2) Why has the Government withdrawn funding from the project without reviewing its progress?

I am advised that the Government has not withdrawn funding. The Office of the NHMRC has not received any reports to date from the organisation and has not received a submission for funding in 1996/97. The Department of Health and Family Services has asked the NHMRC to send a copy of the Final Summary Report and any other reports from the organisation to assist in assessment and negotiation of future funding needs of the Service.

The organisation also receives funding under the Department's Healthy Women—Strong Families initiative which commenced in 1995-96 and will be supported as a recurrent program from 1996-97 with funds provided by the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Services.
(3) What steps has the Minister taken to review the report of the West Australian parliamentary committee's inquiry into the project?

I am advised that the Department of Health and Family Services and the Western Australia Health Department have commenced discussions about outcomes of the project and arrangements for a joint review in July 1996 to determine ongoing funding and service delivery arrangements for the Service.
BACKGROUND:

The Ngunytuju Tjitji Pirni Health Project receives funding from several sources, including two different programs within the Department of Health and Family Services. A three year research project is funded by the Office of the NHMRC and is due to be completed in November 1996.

Informal progress reports on the NHMRC research project and the 1994/95 Steps into the Future Report published by Ngunytju Tjitji Pirni have generated a great deal of support and interest in this initiative both within the Department and with other interested organisations.

Ngunytju Tjitji Pirni has not applied to the NHMRC for funds in 1996/97. Therefore the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Services in my Department is waiting on the Final Summary Report of the NHMRC Research Project to finalise for negotiations with Ngunytju Tjitji Pirni and Western Australian Health Department concerning ongoing funding for this important initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to amendments made by the Senate to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1996 concerning tax concessions for private urban road projects.

Senator Short's trademark in this place is that of an obfuscating, bungling, stumbling incompetent. What he has added to that very doubtful reputation is that of being a misleader. On 19 June, to questions from Senator Faulkner, he misled this chamber over the details of the start date on sales tax. It was inconvenient for him that he then had to later change his information to the Senate but, of course, he never changed it all. He failed to withdraw the blackguarding he had engaged in against Senator Faulkner, and he conducted himself in a manner that can only be described as churlish in the extreme. That is strike one.

Strike two occurred yesterday and today when Senator Short again misled this chamber. It is very important to get the facts of this misleading clear so that the degree of misleading can be understood and therefore appreciated. Yesterday he received a question from Senator Kernot about the Development Allowance Authority and, rather than answer the question that Senator Kernot had posed to Senator Short, Senator Short rounded on Senator Kernot, attacked her and accused her in about a five‐ or six‐paragraph answer of sabotaging some 40 projects in all in this country to the value of $2.5 billion.

When one looks at Senator Short's answer one can see he used the words `sabotage' or `sabotaged' at least eight times. There is no doubt, there is no ambiguity at all, that he meant to directly say that Senator Kernot, and those of us in the opposition and other minor parties who had voted for an amendment when this bill was before the chamber, had sabotaged those projects. Today, when asked whether he withdrew or changed those words, he reaffirmed them. So for the second day in a row he used words which, unfortunately for him, do not in any way, shape of form equate with the truth.

Mr President, it is unparliamentary to use the appropriate word that one might use in these circumstances, and I decline to use that word. But it is parliamentary to say in these circumstances that a misleading has occurred, and it has occurred for this reason: the bill in question was passed by this chamber. That is not a small fact. It is the large fact that sits awkwardly in front of Senator Short that, if the bill had not been passed, then there may have been some grounds for arguing the case—although they would have been, it has to be said, weak grounds, but a skilful advocate may have made something stronger from them.

But there are no grounds because the bill was passed, and passed with one amendment. It is therefore important to dwell for a moment on that amendment to see whether there is any comfort for Senator Short's extraordinary misleading in regard to that one amendment. Of course there is not. That one amendment referred only and exclusively to road construction in Australia from, I recall, 15 December 1995.

The only projects that would have been affected by that amendment are road constructions that would have attracted the development allowance authority grant from 15 December 1995, and not anything else. The projects that Senator Short referred to that make up the $2.5 billion are projects which he has itemised as follows: 18 projects in the mining industry—not true; 10 projects in the tourism industry—not true; six projects in electricity, gas and water—not true; four projects in manufacturing—not true. The three projects in transport and storage are more than likely not true although he has declined to give information about those projects.

When my office rang the Development Allowance Authority during question time yesterday to seek verification, they said they would fax the information. When it did not come through my fax, they told us they had received a call from the office of the Treasurer and that, if we want the information, we have to write to the Treasurer.

This is not a question that the Senate should take lightly. There is nothing that has happened here that has sabotaged those projects. To say that it has is to mislead. To continue to say it is to mislead again and offend twice. Senator Short should do the decent thing and now apologise and withdraw. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, when I heard Senator Short answer my question yesterday, at first I thought he may not have known what the Treasurer had announced earlier in the day. I thought he simply knew that we were debating the Development Allowance Authority Bill and he had not heard that the Treasurer had made a separate announcement. But listening to the end of the answer and hearing what you have repeated today, it is my view that you have misled the Senate. I believe you have misled us in two ways.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I think you have been wrong about the amount you have stated because, as I understand it from the financial impact statement of the bill, we are talking about $920 million dollars, not $2.5 billion. Secondly, as Senator Peter Cook has explained, it is misleading to say that anything has been sabotaged when the bill has been passed. What it in fact means is that now the government has a choice. It has a choice whether it accepts the extension that they were asking for in the bill to the new applications which have come in after the closing date and the Senate amendment which says no to the reinstatement of urban roads as qualifying for infrastructure tax concessions, or whether it says no to the lot. It is the government's choice. It is very misleading to say, when a bill has been passed, that something has been sabotaged.

I want to revisit why the Democrats moved the amendment we did, because it has been misrepresented as well. We added a provision to the bill which affects only 40 privately constructed toll roads, not the 40 private projects that you were talking about. The Economic Planning Advisory Commission, the private infrastructure task force that was set up in October, looked at infrastructure borrowing tax concessions for the builders of private tollways. It said that privately financed projects are likely to be least advantageous for urban roads and that there was little efficiency to be gained from private ownership.

You are the people who go on about efficiency all the time—making taxpayers' money work efficiently—and you try and reinstate a rort which gives a benefit to private developers and asks taxpayers to pay three times—through petrol, then to the tax collector, and then to the toll collector at the toll booths—for the privilege of using roads in New South Wales.
That is the point. You are the ones that go on about efficiencies and you are the ones that are reinstating a very inefficient tax. Mr Costello's supposedly independent Commission of Audit said:
It is not apparent within the current income tax arrangements why special tax treatment should apply to infrastructure borrowings.
That is the point. We should revisit the Treasurer's words when we are asking why this government, preoccupied with efficiency, chooses to reintroduce a rort.
We should also revisit why the Treasurer said, when he was saying that it was not right for some state governments and local governments to have cars that were sales tax exempt:
Don't think that the government will sit by and allow the existing tax system to be riddled and rorted.

He sought to reintroduce a huge rort. That is the point, and that is why the Senate acted as it did. We said that we do not accept this. It has nothing to do with the construction of Sydney's eastern distributor. Tollways are incredibly profitable, and that is why investors are lining up to invest in them. That is the fact. When you say that we sabotaged something, Senator Short, I ask you to look again. This Senate passed the bill. The government got what it asked for. It got a little bit more that it did not want, as well. The choice is yours, but you have misled the Senate on two counts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALKER.NAME: Senator GIBSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to advise the Senate that what Senator Kernot has just been saying is really inappropriate. She is wrong. The other day when the bill was here in this place, she raised the matter of roads as a separate issue from what the bill, which was going through the Senate at the time, was about. The DAA bill was about making sure that 35 major projects in Australia were able to restructure their affairs and still claim the development allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, it was encouraging investment in Australia for the long term of Australia. If Senator Kernot and the Democrats and others wanted to raise the issue of roads or funding for roads, which is a separate issue, the more appropriate way to do it would have been to bring in her own bill about amending the development allowance act.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said in the debate that we can do it: it was appropriate; it was relevant.

—But it was not appropriate. Instead of actually bringing in a separate bill and pursuing the argument of whether or not roads should be included in the infrastructure bonds part of that act, the Australian Democrats organised a diversionary tactic, resulting in this bill being unacceptable. It has gone through the Senate with an unacceptable amendment which has nothing to do with the original intention of making sure the development allowance is available to the 35 special projects, mostly mining projects, as outlined by Senator Short. Senator Kernot did it in the full knowledge that the government's policy was to support the infrastructure bonds for roads.
—Aren't we allowed to have amendments any more?

—Yes, of course you are. But because it was a completely separate issue from the one which was at hand, you muddied the water knowing full well that the government would not be able to accept the amendment that you proposed. The bill has already gone back through the other place where the government has rejected the amendment. The bill is due to come back here, and the government is not in a position to accept that amendment. The consequence will be that the 35 projects that people entered into in good faith, with the support of the Australian Labor Party when in government previously—
—And they can still have them.
—Yes, but all muddied by the amendment moved in here.
—We passed them.

—Yes, I know we passed it; the Senate did pass it. But this government is committed to keeping infrastructure bonds open to a wide range of infrastructure—and we do not want to debate whether roads should be in or out now; the coalition is committed to having roads in and we should have that debate some other time. But this is a specific issue to try to give relief to ownership structure for particular, mostly mining projects—35 of them. We now have the consequences of that because you have deliberately set out to ambush this, as you knew that the government was committed to the roads policy with regard to infrastructure bonds.

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats organised this, supported by the opposition, knowing full well the consequences of what they were doing. They stand condemned by the government. They stand condemned by those companies and all their supporters, including all their employees who have basically been misled as to what they should be doing with those projects. They entered into these projects in good faith, encouraged by the Labor Party when they were in government, thinking that they would actually get this development allowance of the tax relief of 10 per cent on the capital cost of the project. The Democrats and the opposition stand condemned for this ambush tactic on the 35 major projects for the development allowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gibson, of course, accuses the Australian Labor Party of participating in some sort of ambush and sabotage of a government bill on the Development Allowance Authority. Nothing could be further from the truth. The whole issue was raised by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the other place on the question of the infrastructure bonds applying to roads. He did it in such a deliberately provocative way and sought to overturn the decisions made by Ralph Willis and Laurie Brereton who, on 15 December last year, announced changes to the infrastructure borrowing arrangements for urban roads. The very simple reason was that the application of infrastructure bonds to urban roads, particularly given the City Link project in Melbourne, would have been totally uneconomic and would have led to major distortions and quite savage abuses of the policy processes in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: City Link, a project worth $1.2 billion with an additional cost of finance of some $0.7 billion, under these sordid, secret arrangements would have ended up costing between $7 billion and $8 billion. Its construction costs alone were $1.2 billion. For 34 years, profits would have been guaranteed to the City Link consortia involving Transurban. Individual taxpayers, individual commuters in Melbourne, would have to pay for some 34 years the equivalent, in today's prices, of $1,500 a year for the use of those roads—public assets which were funded by the public purse over many years but transferred to the private sector. By extraordinary means, with additional subsidies to the tune of $300 million added to the project but not funded by the private consortia, a construction project which should have cost $1.2 billion would have ended up costing between $7 billion and $8 billion over the 34‐year life of the project.

On top of that, some 66 measures were introduced in the Victorian parliament to ensure that anti‐competitive actions would provide additional subsidies and protections—and to avoid the normal, common civil rights. As a result of the infrastructure bonds, uneconomic actions have been taken with a major distortion to the transport options provided to the City of Melbourne.

This is a substantial policy issue that does not relate to ambush or sabotage. The matter was soundly and properly raised by the former Treasurer, Mr Ralph Willis, and the former Minister for Transport, Mr Laurie Brereton. They indicated that private road builders had inflated the construction costs through legal and financial complexities and had provided a risk premium to such an extent that there was a guaranteed profit. These actions resulted in the public purse being fleeced.

What your government is trying to do is reintroduce those extraordinary rorts. You are trying to fleece the public of this country by allowing this action to proceed. The Senate has amended a bill that you have brought in here. It has not asked you to exempt those other measures; it has not sought to stop the other 35 projects. What it says is that you should exclude privatised roads—the transfer of a public asset to a private monopoly, in the case of Transurban and examples like that in the future—in such a way as to protect the public interest. You are seeking to avoid that obligation. For you to come in here and say that we are sabotaging the program of the government is totally inappropriate and just plain wrong.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that I absolutely and totally reject any assertion that I have misled the Senate over this matter. Once again, you find that in this chamber Senator Cook plays very lightly indeed with the truth. I have to say that that does Senator Cook no credit at all. He has never had credibility in this place; he was the most pumped up minister the place has ever seen, a pompous minister who did not really know what he was talking about—and he is carrying it on in opposition. I do not want to continue with that attack on a personal level. So far as Senator Kernot is concerned, she appears to have totally misunderstood the situation.
—That is being generous.

—I will be generous. The key point is that the Australian Democrats on Monday deliberately moved an amendment in the Senate that they knew was going to be unacceptable to the government. They knew the government could not accept that amendment. As I understand it—I may be wrong and Senator Kernot can correct me—I don't think they even thought of having the amendment until Mr Costello answered a question on it during question time in the House of Representatives. There had been no prior warning or indication that such an amendment was going to come forward.

BREAK.PARA: I repeat the point that the Democrats introduced an amendment which really had nothing to do with the bill at hand. What the bill was about was basically a technical amendment to enable a wide range of projects in the mining industry, in tourism and so on, to qualify for the development allowance. The termination cut‐off date for applications was way back on 1 January 1993. What the bill was about was a minor technical amendment which, as I recall, the previous government had announced last year that they were going to do, but did not get around to doing it. That was all the bill was about.

What then happened was that Senator Kernot heard a question and answer on the development allowance application as far as private urban roads were concerned. The Democrats thought, `Gee, this would be a pretty good idea. We will do something about this and tack it on as an amendment to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill that was in the Senate.' They knew when they did that that the government could not accept that amendment. That is why I say, and why I said on Monday, that by moving this amendment, which they knew to be unacceptable, they have put the whole bill at risk.
That was the point I made in my response yesterday to the question from Senator Kernot. That is why I said in the first sentence yesterday in my response to Senator Kernot:

The actions of the Australian Democrats supported by the Australian Labour Party here yesterday in amending the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill . . . threatened to sabotage approximately 40 projects in this country . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —You said `sabotaged'.

—My first reference was `threatened to sabotage' and then I shorthanded it, of course, and said `sabotage'. In effect, you have threatened to sabotage; you have put at grave jeopardy the ability of those 40 projects to qualify under the Development Allowance Authority Act. You have done that deliberately. You knew that the amendment you moved on roads was totally unacceptable to the government. For Senator Kernot now to say, as she did in her response, that we have a choice is a statement of the most extreme arrogance. Are we in government supposed to say yes or no, that this would be a good or bad thing, depending on whether the Democrats allow us to do it? Of course not. (Time expired)

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bob Collins today, relating to funding for the Community Development Employment Projects program of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

The minister said a number of things in that answer. First, he said, `It will only take a phone call to fix this problem up.' What concerned me most was that he made a number of other assertions. He said that all the people involved, including the ATSIC officers, were engaged in `mischievous behaviour'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Some.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be in the Hansard . Mr Peter Boothman from ATSIC will be interested to know that he is a mischief maker. The minister also said that the only reason this organisation Junjuwa could be having this problem was that they must have a serious budget problem.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to correct the record. I said that they made two telephone calls this morning. The first of those calls was yesterday afternoon, which makes this story even worse. I will present the facts fairly to the Senate as I understand them. All of this was totally unsolicited by me. This is the sad and sorry track record of this matter with this organisation.

Junjuwa is the largest Aboriginal community in the Fitzroy Valley. The chairman of the ATSIC regional council, Dick Bedford, yesterday signed the decision papers for CDEP grants to the local communities, including this one. Normally the money would start flowing from today. This community first faxed a letter to Senator Herron on Monday morning this week. All these letters, I might add, are not confrontationist; they are letters pleading for help. The council was hanging on every word Senator Herron said in this place.

They wrote to him first on Monday morning. They wrote to him again yesterday morning. Junjuwa spoke to an adviser in the minister's office yesterday afternoon and was told there were transitional arrangements. The adviser in the minister's office yesterday afternoon said that if they had no budget problems they would be cleared and would have access to those transitional funds. I acknowledge that that is exactly what the minister said in here today. That was yesterday afternoon.

They then informed the adviser that this was in direct contradiction to what the local ATSIC office was telling them. You could imagine the confusion on the ground here. They then relayed the answer of the minister's adviser to the ATSIC office and asked them, not unreasonably, to put their advice in writing. The ATSIC office did. I seek leave to table the letter.
Leave granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter is self‐explanatory. They wrote to the minister again last night. I seek leave to table this letter.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter is again self‐explanatory. It pleadingly says, `Please help us. We will be on the phone at 6 o'clock this morning.' They were, because I checked. They said, `Please ring us and tell us why we are getting written advice from the ATSIC office that conflicts with what the minister is saying in the parliament. Ring us. We have a deadline.' The officer in the minister's office said, `Fine.'

ANSWER.PARA: They waited until the last possible minute—the time difference meant that it was 11 o'clock this morning—to ring the minister's office, only to be told that no-one was available to take their call.
