TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the 18th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The government's response read as follows—

ROW.ENTRY: Response to the Eighteenth Report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation

2.1 The Committee recommends that the Government reconsider the legislative requirement that the Tribunal must include the Chair or Deputy Chair when exercising its powers and assess whether it would enhance the timeliness of the Tribunal to have a less restrictive provision such as those found in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, Social Security Act and the Migration Act.

The Government does not agree that the requirement that review panels must include the Chairperson or Deputy Chairperson unduly constrains the Tribunal's efficiency. The majority of complaints lodged with the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal (SCT) are resolved at the inquiry and conciliation stages by the Tribunal Secretariat and only a small proportion (4 per cent of all complaints within jurisdiction received from July 1994 to March 1996) require review by a Tribunal Panel. Tribunal reviews are regularly programmed by the Tribunal Secretariat and, while the proportion of complaints requiring review may increase in future (particularly in relation to disability complaints involving medical evidence), there is no basis for concluding that the requirement that the Chairperson or Deputy Chairperson must be a part of the panel impedes the timeliness of the review process at present, or is likely to do so in the foreseeable future.

In addition, there are a number of benefits that flow from requiring one or other of the Chairperson or Deputy Chairperson to be present on all review panels. First, it ensures continuity and stability in the determination making process and will maximise the likelihood of consistent Tribunal decisions emerging in similar fact situations. While the Tribunal, as a merits review body, is not bound by its past determinations, broad consistency of outcomes is an important factor in maintaining industry and public confidence in the Tribunal, particularly where potentially large sums of privately accumulated retirement savings and ancillary entitlements are involved, and given the avid industry attention paid to the written determinations.

Second, it provides for an efficient division of responsibilities between the two full‐time office holders—the Chairperson and Deputy Chairperson—who are selected for their ability to administer and conduct Tribunal panels, on the one hand, and the pool of part‐time members, who are selected for their expertise in relation to the subject matter of particular superannuation complaints, on the other hand.

2.2 The Committee recommends that the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal develop a charter of access and service, using those developed by the Federal Court, the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as a model.

The Government agrees that the SCT should develop a charter of access and service with a view to setting standards for all aspects of its dealings with the public. In the development of a SCT charter, regard would be had to similar documents developed by other tribunals and courts.

4.1 The Committee recommends that all superannuation fund members, including members of excluded funds, should have access to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. The Committee has reservations about the participation in excluded funds of employee members and is of the view that such membership should be discouraged.

The Government is of the view that excluded fund members are typically non‐arms length members, for example, family members or business associates, who can be expected to communicate frequently with each other and be able to resolve any disputes by other means without the need for SCT conciliation and review.

The Committee's concerns about arms‐length members who have no choice in becoming a member of an excluded fund, for example, employees of a small business, are exaggerated, and are better addressed by other means, for example, inter alia, through Government policies to allow greater choice in the placement of compulsory superannuation contributions.
5.1 The Committee recommends that where possible the trustees should provide reasons for their decisions.

The Tribunal Chairperson has indicated publicly that the SCT expects trustees to record reasons for their decisions. The Government also regards adequate record keeping as best practice. Trustees who fail to record reasons may find themselves at a disadvantage before the SCT because it will be difficult for the Tribunal to decide if the trustee has acted fairly or reasonably if it does not have access to all material considered and the trustee's reasoning for its decision. The Government is presently of the view that the SCT's stance on this matter will encourage trustees to provide reasons and thereby lead to the desired outcome without the need for legislative amendment. However, the situation will continue to be monitored by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and legislative amendment may need to be considered in the future.

6.1 The Committee recommends that a limited Government funded superannuation consumer advice service be established within the existing community legal or credit advice centres; that there be a general limit of two appointments for each client; and that the service be restricted to providing advice and information only and not extend to the running of cases before the Tribunal. The Committee further recommends that this arrangement be reviewed after two years and an assessment as to its adequacy be made at that time.

Government funding for a superannuation consumer advice service is not considered necessary given the measures already in place to assist members of superannuation funds with their complaints. These measures include the obligation on the SCT to assist a person in making a complaint, the legislative requirement that the existence and functions of the SCT be disclosed to all members upon joining and each year, the provision of an interpreter service for complainants where necessary, the fact that the SCT can be contacted from anywhere in Australia for the cost of a local call, the production and wide distribution of a simple and easy to read publication on how to lodge complaints with the SCT. Regional Offices of the ISC also assist people who want to make complaints to the SCT, there is no application fee for lodging a complaint with the SCT, and no costs are charged to the member or the fund.

The Government considers that the SCT and its secretariat can be relied upon to provide accurate and impartial assistance in resolving complaints, and that the spirit of alternative dispute resolution—particularly, the role of direct communication and conciliation in a non‐adversarial context—should be maintained.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign, Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Foreign, Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee entitled Australia China Relations together with the transcript of proceedings and submissions received by the committee.

I wish to make some very brief remarks. Firstly, it is my great privilege to be the chair of the Senate Foreign, Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee in the new parliament. I would like to put on the record the great contribution made to this committee by three retiring senators—Senator Teague, Senator Jones and Senator Burns—all of whom played a major role in the compilation of this important report on our relations with China. I would also like to pay tribute to the work of Senator West and Senator Ellison, who also were very instrumental in the preparation of this report.

Finally, I would like to thank Paul Barsdell, the secretary; Alistair Sands, the principal research officer; Dolores Young, the executive assistant; and all the other staff of the secretariat of the committee. They have worked long and tirelessly to complete this report in time, which I am certain will be a major contribution to the ongoing development of our relations with China.

I would like to leave my remarks there, in view of the fact that I know a couple of other senators do wish to make a contribution. Therefore, I seek leave to have the remainder of my remarks, with respect to the tabling speech, incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
AUSTRALIA CHINA RELATIONS

I am pleased to table this report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee on Australia‐China Relations. It is an extensive review of one of Australia's most important bilateral relationships that has been conducted at a time of significant change, not only within China itself, but also within the Asia‐Pacific region and globally. China's economy continues to change rapidly as the Chinese Government strives to build a socialist market economy. China is also on the brink of ushering in the age of the second‐generation leaders. The leadership has followed the broad policies espoused by Deng Xiaoping and, in particular, is now united on the importance of maintaining market‐based reform of the economy.

The Committee has also taken into account international factors affecting China and its relationship with Australia. Both countries are members of the Asia Pacific Economic Co‐operation and the more recently formed ASEAN Regional Forum. This reflects the common interests both countries have in seeing that peace and stability prevail in the Asia Pacific. Yet there are a number of tensions and potential flash points which threaten the current state of relative calm in the region. Taiwan and the South China Sea are two such regional concerns, while China's harder line on Hong Kong of late and the recurring tensions in China‐United States relations have also affected the atmosphere in the region.

These domestic and international developments are all of interest to Australia, both in the context of its relationship with China and Australia's overall engagement with Asia. Thus the Committee's inquiry and report has been opportune.

It should be noted that this is the second inquiry involving Australia and China conducted by a Senate committee. In 1983‐84, the former Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade conducted an inquiry into prospects for Australia‐China trade. However, this is the first time that a parliamentary committee has reviewed the wider bilateral relationship.

As a starting point, the Committee agreed that Australia's relationship with China should be based on friendship but still be business‐like in order to pursue national interests and enhance mutual interests. The relationship should also be based on respect, understanding and trust and be robust enough to discuss sensitive issues without affecting the stability of the relationship.

The relationship has been reasonably good but there are still thorny issues which will test the strength of the relationship. However, the relationship has endured previous rough stretches and the Committee is confident that the relationship has matured enough to deal with difficult issues without compromising the integrity of the relationship.

In any bilateral relationship, both sides have to work hard to sustain the harmony and productiveness of that relationship, particularly where the two countries have fundamentally different political and social systems, as do Australia and China. This requires frequent contact at all levels of government to build up the understanding and trust necessary to ride over any rough patches which may occur in any relationship.

The importance of building understanding and trust at all levels of the bilateral relationship, from the governmental level through to commercial ties and defence exchanges, is a major theme running through the report. Mutual understanding depends on both countries learning more about each other, in terms of language, culture, people and perceptions. Central to this two‐way learning process is the need for exchanges of people across all the areas of the relationship. These exchanges should help cultivate trust which is an important antidote for fear and misperception that can damage relationships, particularly during periods of difficulty and friction.

In light of recent tensions in the region, the development of cultural and social relations continue to be as important and relevant now as they were at the time of the establishment of diplomatic relations between Australia and China in 1972, when China was a more closed society. The Committee has recommended an increase in the real level of resources available to the Australia‐China Council (ACC) for its work in developing social and cultural ties and for its support of bilateral economic relations to a level similar to that in the ACC's first years of activities. The Committee has also recommended that the Department of Employment, Education and Training at least maintain funding levels for Chinese language and cultural studies in Australia and encourage State Government education authorities to do likewise.

Commerce continues to be at the heart of Australia‐China relations. A significant section of the report and over half of the Committee's recommendations to the Government focus on economic and investment matters. This largely reflects the common view that the trading connection between Australia and China is the mainstay of the overall relationship.

The economic relationship has both grown and changed significantly since the first Senate Committee report on Australia‐China trade in 1983‐84. In 1982‐83, total two‐way trade was worth $890 million. In 1995 it was worth nearly $7 billion.

Currently bilateral trade is growing at close to 20 per cent annually. China is Australia's fastest growing export market in East Asia. Australian investment in China is growing even faster, having doubled in the time since the inquiry began. Australia is the second most important destination, after Hong Kong, for Chinese overseas investment.

What these figures do not show, however, is the growing sophistication and maturity of the economic relationship. As both economies have changed internally over the last 15 years, so too has the nature of the trade between them changed. Commodity exports remain the core of Australia's exports to China, but they have fallen as a proportion of total exports with the rise of exports of raw materials and energy products needed for China's economic transformation, and with the entry of Australian manufactures and services into the China market. Chinese exports to Australia have also changed qualitatively, with traditional labour‐intensive exports falling as a proportion of total exports with the rise of light industrial exports and exports of more sophisticated electrical and machine goods.

The economic relationship looks set to expand further and this should be a high priority for Australia in its relations with China. With China's economy booming and foreign investment and aid sought, China offers considerable opportunities for the Australian business community across a breadth of sectors. Australia is well‐placed to capitalise on the market openings offered by China's economic transformation. Apart from the natural complementarity between the two economies, Australia has established in China a reputation as a fair and reliable trader. The sound state of the political relationship, and Australia's image as a non‐threatening regional neighbour, mean that commercial links are not hamstrung by some of the political tensions other western trading partners experience in China.

Australia's fast‐growing investment presence in China also promises to generate follow‐on export business for Australian companies. As investment is now seen as driving trade, especially in North East Asian markets such as China's, Australian investment in China has strengthened Australia's long‐term strategic position in the Chinese economy.

However, there is a view that Australia has not made the most of the opportunities presented by the China market. The recent performance of Australian manufactures to China, for example, has been inconsistent. What appears to be at the root of this problem is a lack of strategic commitment to exporting from Australian companies. Such an approach is a recipe for failure in the competitive China market. As the report makes clear, success in China depends on building long‐term relations and a track record for reliability—hallmarks of Australia's success in primary product exports to China. The Committee has recommended that the East Asia Analytical Unit of the Department of Foreign Affairs undertake analysis of Australian manufactures exports and East Asian markets, and report to the Government accordingly.

The Committee also recommends that the Government should conduct a study of the opportunities for Australian business presented by the emergence of regional markets in China. China is commonly described as "one country, many markets. Many of those markets are forming along regional lines, and some present opportunities for which Australian companies should be well‐placed to take advantage. While some Australian companies have begun to explore and enter these emerging markets, the Committee believes more needs to be known about the long‐term market potential, as well as the obstacles and risks, of these regional markets before Australian companies will begin to see them as viable alternatives to China's coastal markets.

In reviewing Australia's economic performance in China, the Committee looked at the overall approach employed by Australia and, in particular, the role of government in assisting Australia's economic interests. Government support remains crucial in a market such as China's. Chinese officials and customers see it as a seal of approval on the value of a private company's bid, a factor which helps overcome some of the limitations Australian small to medium‐sized enterprises (SMEs) face when up against larger competitors from the united States or Japan. Government support also helps open doors in an economic system where personal connections are all‐important, and can prove essential if business people run into complications with China's opaque and arbitrary regulatory system.

Yet the role of government in the relationship is changing, if not declining with both the rise of the non‐state sector in China but also the growing presence of Australian companies in China. These developments necessitate some degree of change in the way Australia conducts business in China. The Committee believes that the peak bilateral government body, the Joint Ministerial Economic Council (JMEC), should be retained to oversee economic relations between Australia and China. But the Committee recommends a review of the level below the JMEC, the Joint Working Groups (JWGs), to examine whether there needs to be changes made to ensure that the JWGs reflect the devolution of economic power and regionalism of the Chinese economy.

The Committee also sees the JMEC operating as an umbrella for the new groupings that are forming amongst Australian companies. The Committee strongly endorses the merger of the Australia China Business Council and Australia China Chambers of Commerce and Industry which is imminent. Likewise, it also supports the merger of a number of Australian Business Groups based in Hong Kong and major centres in China. The formation of these united bodies should help project a clear Australian identity in the China market and overcome some of the disunity that has been a problem for Australia in China.

Despite China's open door policies and continued relaxation of restrictions on foreign involvement in its economy, the China market still presents significant obstacles and challenges for Australian companies. China is a high‐cost and high‐risk market. Tariff and non‐tariff barriers remain at levels far higher than those in Australia, which is one of the reasons for Australia's current trade deficit with China. While it has a large body of law, much of it is opaque and its enforcement arbitrary.

These problems make it essential that China joins the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on the basis of an unequivocal commitment from China to the WTO's rules‐based standards and market disciplines. Any compromise of the WTO's rules for the sake of securing China's membership would not only undermine the basis of the liberalised international trade system but would also reduce the momentum for further market reform of the Chinese economy. The Committee has recommended that the Government continue to press, at both the bilateral and multilateral level, for China to accede to the WTO on the basis of a clear commitment from China to implement WTO rules within clearly specified timeframes.

The Committee has also recommended that steps be taken towards establishing a bilateral program of work experience exchanges between Australian and Chinese companies. Such an exchange program would meet the current priority China places on acquiring modern management and technical skills from advanced economies. It would also increase mutual understanding of the different economic systems and business cultures in both countries which should help overcome both Chinese misperceptions of the Australian economy and the difficulties Australian companies encounter when trying to thread there way through China's complex economic system.

The Committee supports but wishes to see enlarged the approach adopted by Australia towards China on defence. Strategic engagement with China, rather than containment or moves to isolate China, should remain the guiding principle of Australian foreign and defence policy, unless circumstances change dramatically.

The Committee recommends the development of officer exchanges between the Australian Defence Force and the People's Liberation Army as an important measure for building better understanding between the two countries on defence and regional security issues. This would not only complement the bilateral strategic dialogue that currently takes place between both countries' defence establishments but should also help develop channels of communication that are important both for avoiding misperceptions and during periods of difficulty. Such contacts would be a step towards Australia's larger goal of engaging China more deeply in the evolving network of multilateral regional security ties.

The Committee also recommends that the Australian Government should encourage China to publish a white paper on China's defence policy and military development. One of the reasons for concern within the region over China's growing but still modest power projection capabilities is the lack of transparency surrounding China's defence planning. The uncertainty over China's long‐term strategic ambitions arising from this lack of transparency has the potential to breed hostile perceptions towards China. To avoid this occurring, China needs to be encouraged to embrace both the letter and the spirit of defence transparency.

The Committee has also recommended that a priority in Australian policy towards South China Sea should be the promotion of efforts to establish a multilateral framework for conflict prevention in the South China Sea. Although the situation in the South China Sea remains relatively low‐key, the fact that the military forces of the various claimants operate often in close proximity points to the risk of an accident happening that could escalate to a higher level. Establishing a framework for conflict prevention would help counter such incidents occurring.

With regard to human rights in China, the Committee supports Australia's policy of constructive, non‐confrontational dialogue with China on these matters. The Committee believes that linking sanctions in other areas to improvements in human rights is neither productive in maintaining a viable relationship with China nor effective in producing the desired improvements. The breadth of Australia's connections with China at all levels of the relationship offers channels through which Australia make it concerns known and sensitise Chinese people to international accepted standards of human rights behaviour.

Australia has significant interests in both Hong Kong and Taiwan. Hong Kong is Australia's tenth largest trading partner and a major destination of Australian overseas investment. It is in Australia's interests that there is a smooth transition in Hong Kong between British and Chinese rule and that all commitments made in relation to the future of Hong Kong are honoured on all sides. Maintaining the right to exercise personal freedoms in Hong Kong after 1997 is crucial both for the human rights of the Hong Kong people but also to the health of the Hong Kong economy and overseas confidence in its stability, two factors which are in turn important to China's won economic interests. The Committee believes that the Australian Government should monitor developments in Hong Kong and make appropriate representations to China if such human rights are restricted.

Since the establishment of diplomatic relations with China in 1972, Australia has regarded Taiwan as a province of China and accordingly has not had political relations with Taiwan. This has not precluded Australia developing a strong economic relationship with Taiwan. Taiwan is now Australia's ninth largest trading partner. In pursuing an economic relationship with Taiwan, a country, which has diplomatic relations with China, may find it difficult to keep that relationship solely within the bounds of the economic sphere. In such circumstances, arrangements might be entered into with Taiwan, which in the opinion of China cross the line into the political arena and thus provoke protests from Beijing. Openness with China should help to allay any Chinese concerns that Australia is not adhering to its responsibilities under the 1972 agreement. That is not to say that Australia and China might disagree on whether some action by Australia in relation to Taiwan is consistent with Australia's obligations. As it is a bilateral agreement, the terms of that agreement are subject to interpretation by both sides. If Australia and China do not interpret something in the same way, they should try to achieve accommodation through discussion and negotiation. The Committee does not believe, however, that one side has the right to insist that its view should always prevail. Provided that both sides adhere to the fundamental principles underpinning the relationship, there should be recognition given to the dynamic nature of the relationship, as well as to the regional and global environment, by the adoption of a reasonable approach to new policies. Both sides need, however, to negotiate on the basis of their national interests in good faith.

The Committee endorses the Australian Government's policy of not supporting Taiwan's efforts to put on the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly the question of appropriate representation for Taiwan's population. This is an internal matter for China and Taiwan to work out between themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague, Sen Baden

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in supporting the speech of the now chairman of the Senate Foreign, Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee and to welcome and endorse fully this important report entitled Australia China Relations . I happened to be directly involved in the formulation of the terms of reference that came to the Senate and I have worked very closely with other senators over a three-year period now in the determination of the 12 chapters and the 23 recommendations of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a comprehensive assessment of the relationship between Australia and China—that is, it deals with the political relationship, the economic relationship, and social and cultural aspects of the relationship. It deals with particular parts of the economy—with commerce, with trade, with joint ventures, with investment from one country to the other and with every aspect of our growing economic relationship.

The terms of reference also required us to directly assess the concerns of Australians in China relating to human rights. A full chapter was devoted to this in the report. We were also required in our terms of reference to look at the situation in Taiwan and Hong Kong. Sometimes we referred to three Chinas. Of course, there is only one China—and we recognise the republic in Beijing as China—but we are aware of the separation, at least for the time being, of Taiwan and Hong Kong as British colonies which are to be handed back to China in a year's time.

There are very real concerns in Australia about the particularities of the second and third Chinas, as they are colloquially called, when looking at this part of Asia. I think that there is a mature and well developed assessment of each of these economies in the report. There is bipartisan support to maximise Australia's commercial relationship with Taiwan and to in no way whatsoever change the political relationship which exists—that is, that we recognise the government of China in Beijing.

We also encourage, as the representatives of China and Taiwan see fit, the negotiations for a harmonious and peaceful relationship of more and more substance between China and Taiwan. We see it as being in the interests of China, Hong Kong and Australia that there is a stable transition in a year's time when Hong Kong reverts back to Chinese sovereignty.

BREAK.PARA: In the introduction to the report there is reference to five members of the committee visiting China. The chair of the committee was my very good friend Senator Gerry Jones. I was deputy chairman of the committee during that period. Accompanying us on the visit were Senator Chris Ellison, Senator Sue West, Senator Bryant Burns and the secretary, Paul Barsdell. We had a wonderful team approach while we were visiting China and it directly affected the way in which we received scores of submissions for our inquiry. That all helped in the writing of our report.

I want to acknowledge and thank, as we do in the report, the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National People's Congress of China—in particular, the chairman, Mr Zhu Liang, whom I have met on several visits to China, and the deputy chairman, Mr Zhu Qizhen, who has served as China's ambassador to the United States. These two gentlemen are extraordinarily experienced in foreign affairs matters relating to the China.

We visited Beijing, Lanzhou in Gansu Province, Qingdao, Shanghai and Shenzhen. We wanted to visit the major cities, Beijing and Shanghai. We wanted to visit some coastal regions in this part of Shandong and Shenzhen near Qingdao, but we also wanted to go to an inland region. In this case, it was the capital of Gansu Province.

While we were in Hong Kong we were able to meet with Governor Patten, the senior Chinese official in Hong Kong, Mr Zhou Nan, and the President of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong, the Hon. John Swaine. These three discussions were of great value to us and formed the chapter we have on Hong Kong.

In the couple of minutes remaining, I wish to refer to the growing prospects of Australia having economic and other relationships with China which will be of mutual benefit to the two countries. Before I make those few remarks, I wish to join the chairman and the whole committee in thanking the secretary of the committee, Mr Paul Barsdell, the research officer, Alistair Sands, and the other staff for their professional work and diligent personal assistance to us. Three years ago there were others who assisted this committee, but they no longer make up the secretariat of the committee. They are first‐class members of the Department of the Senate and I thank them very sincerely for their work. I thank the members of the committee for the care they took on the committee.

The final remarks I wish to make relate to the 70‐year period which began in 1980. That was when Deng Xiaoping gained full political support, after the 10 lost years of the cultural revolution, for the open door policy. For the first time in history, China actually began to emerge into the modern world. Prior to that there was the cultural revolution, the ups and downs of Mao Tse‐tung's period since 1949, the civil war, the Japanese aggression, the war lord period and the period of imperialism that cut up and divided China. Before that there was the dynastic history without which we would not see the strengths of the modernisation that we now have in China.

Up until 1979, and the beginning of Deng Xiaoping's open door policy, China was submerged and not living up to its full potential. It is only with the progressive economic policies of modernisation, of realistic economic achievement and of prosperity for the people of China that followed Deng Xiaoping's initiatives that we have seen China given a chance. It has been 17 years that we have observed this. Both in China and in Australia people are looking forward to 2050—a 70‐year period from 1980 to 2050; if you like, a 70‐year period in which it is expected that China will become the biggest gross economy in the world and the largest population in the world. This is of enormous significance for Australia and Australia's relations within APEC and north Asia.

I reiterate, as the committee does in this report and in its recommendations, that we have a bipartisan approach to China in this parliament and in the nation, that Australia, for its own national interest, needs to see its opportunities and to build, in all the ways that we have outlined in this quite large and comprehensive report, a relationship of mutual benefit, of real trust and real openness so that we see the benefits flowing to the Australian and the Chinese people. I have very much enjoyed involvement in this Senate committee and in this report in particular. I commend the report to the Senate and, indeed, to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones, Sen Gerry

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to say how much I enjoyed being on the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, particularly during the period when I was chairman, and then in the period when Michael Forshaw, Bob Woods and Graham Maguire were chairmen. During that time, the real problem that the committee had was to start and finish the China report because of other work that intervened on the committee's time.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most important happenings was when the committee went to China, Hong Kong and Taiwan to look at on‐the‐ground issues that we wanted to relate to the report. I have to thank the ambassador here for his assistance in having the foreign affairs committee of the National People's Congress issue the invitation to the committee to visit China. That, in itself, was a fairly great happening for the committee: to be one of the first Senate committees to go overseas to discuss some of the report that it was preparing at that time.

I also thank the secretary, Paul Barsdell, and his staff for the way in which the report was put together and for the assistance given to committee members on the trip to China and back in Australia where we undertook public inquiries and put down parts of the report. One could run through the report now and talk about some of the recommendations in it, but could I make a further recommendation to members of this Senate and to members interested in foreign affairs that it would be well worth their time and effort to look at the report on China.

PARA.BREAK: I believe, because of the comprehensive way in which the China report has been put together, it would form a basis for either an historical or an up‐to‐date version of what is happening in China today. It would also give encouragement to business people, to foreign affairs people and to other people to undertake some of the recommendations that we make. I will not deal with the recommenda tion that is being discussed in the House of Representatives for the moment. I will leave that to Senator West. We certainly make a recommendation here in relation to the matter that is before the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The visit to China and then to Hong Kong, where we spent some time talking to Governor Patten and to the Chinese main negotiator, Zhou Nan, was probably some of the best time that committee members spent, hearing the views of both men in relation to the handing back of Hong Kong in 1997.

The visit to Taiwan was done in a private capacity. I went, as did Senator Teague. We had discussions with a number of people but I want to relate to the Senate one discussion that I had in Taiwan. We spent some time speaking to some of the people involved in commercial enterprises in Taiwan. One particular person—I will not name people or companies at this stage—bought a high‐rise property in Sydney and established a manufacturing industry making electrical goods, motors and those types of things. I asked him, `Why would you go to Australia to develop an industry?' He said, `I went to Australia for two reasons: firstly, we didn't have the room in Taiwan to expand; and, secondly, we didn't have the labour. In Australia you have the room and you have the labour.'

I then asked him an obvious question coming from someone who was involved in trade unions, `What sort of problems did you have with the Australian workers? Did you have any industrial problems?' He said, `No, we didn't.' I said, `Why would that be?' He said, `Because we made arrangements and agreements before we started the enterprise and we had no problems.' I said, `My second question would be: how many Taiwanese did you employ?' He thought for a while and then said, `One. By the way, if you would like to meet the manager of our world enterprise, I would be only too pleased to introduce him to you.' He brought him in and he was an Australian who had just been appointed the world manager.

What was said to us that day was that governments in Australia should give more encouragement to people from the Asian region to invest in Australia by way of some sort of tax or investment incentive, something to encourage them to come. He said that he came without any and believed that he did the right thing. He also believed that a lot of other business people would invest in Australia, would develop industries and would employ Australians if they were given just that little bit of encouragement. They now have a policy—I think they call it `Looking south'.

The other point I would like to make is that, as well as talking about employment during my discussion with the world manager, I said that there must have been other reasons why he would spend that sort of money in Australia on that sort of development. He told me that there was.

He said that one of the very important points he had to tell me was that, whenever he sells goods that have been manufactured in Australia overseas, he immediately finds a market. They are sought after because they are manufactured in Australia. I asked about the costs in relation to Australian workers, and he said that we were very competitive.

A story like the one Senator Teague and I picked up during the committee investigation is one that we do not hear too often. But that is the sort of story we ought to look at. If we are going to be involved in Asia, we ought to look at ways to encourage some of that Asian investment into Australia, thereby creating employment for Australians and an export industry for Australia. I think it is very important that those points be considered.

I am not sure there is much more I want to say, because I believe that most of the important points are contained in the report. However, I will further express my gratitude to Paul Barsdell, to the secretariat, to the people who assisted us and to the other members of the committee, particularly those who went on the trip to China. There are a lot more stories I could tell, but I know that other committee members have something to say on this report.

The visit to China, Hong Kong and later to Taiwan—for those members who went there—was one of the most valuable trips undertaken by any committee in the Senate. I think that is shown in the basis of the report and its recommendations. I once again say thanks to those members of the committee who played a role in both the trip and the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to participate in the tabling of this report and to speak on it. This is one report that the Senate can stand well proud of. It is one that has taken some considerable time, but I think the content is such that it will be of vital importance and of great value and benefit to many people who are doing business with China and many people who are interested to know more about the great country that it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I was one of those fortunate enough to be invited to visit the country. I welcome having taken that opportunity. It certainly gave me a greater understanding of the country, the customs and the variety within the country. It is a very large country—in fact, larger than Australia. It has a population in the order of 1.2 billion, but its land formation is such that the people are able to live on only 10 per cent or less of it.

The terrain of the country is very harsh. We talk about our harsh terrain here, but they have mountains that cover large areas, including an area which is part of the Himalayas. That harsh terrain adds to their logistics, infrastructure needs and infrastructure variation. One thing that struck me very greatly was the difference between the infrastructure available in Lanzhou, which is in Gansu province in the middle of the country, and the infrastructure around Beijing, Qingdao, Shenzhen and Shanghai. They were vastly different—like cheese and chalk.

I recall the trip by bus from Lanzhou airport to Lanzhou town. The road was under repair, and we took an hour and a half to get to the town and an hour and a half to return a couple of days later. I also recall that the trip caused someone's bottle of mai tai to break, and the smell of mai tai through a bus at five in the morning is not one I would recommend to many people. It is not particularly nice.

The trip did give us a very good understanding of the infrastructure variation that exists in the country and the problems this causes when moving produce and commodities from one side or end to the other. Those problems are dealt with in the report, and they indicate why the coastal regions trade offshore. It is in fact easier for them to import a number of goods and commodities to work with than actually bring them from the far side of the country. That is a very important point to remember.

To the committee secretariat who helped us, I say thank you. To the three members of the committee who after midnight on Sunday will no longer be members of the Senate, I say that I have enjoyed working with the three of you. I have enjoyed your input and our conversations, stories and times together.
There are 23 recommendations in the report. The one I would like to deal with is recommendation 7, which states:

. . . the Committee recommends that the Government reconsider the decision to cease the Concessional Finance Facility (CFF) program in China, taking into account the affect such a move would have on Australia's wider economic and political interests and Australia's humanitarian efforts in China.

The CFF, as this program is called, is actually part of the DIFF program, and DIFF has certainly been causing some interest in the other place. A lot of evidence before us stated that this program had been a major benefit to both China and Australia, and that is very important.
A commercial review was done on Australia's aid program to China. It found that the return on every $100 of official development assistant—called ODA—was close to $300. The review stated:
Some $285 million in development assistance between 1981 and 1992 generated total business of $883 million.

They are the sorts of benefits that this program has given to Australia, but there have been follow on benefits as well. Because our companies have been in the country and worked with the people, there has been follow on business, with no assistance from the government or anything like that attached to it. Those companies have been able to get the foothold they need with the assistance from this program, and then expand their business into that country with a very beneficial effect.

The Australia‐China Chamber of Commerce was alone in raising the issue of community development and the pursuit of commercial objectives. They called for the balance to move further towards the commercial side, despite the program having moved in the right direction over the past five years. However, they stated that Australia's development assistance must continue to fulfil community development obligations as well as be trade focused.

We heard stories of a desalination plant project undertaken by Memtec in Lanzhou. That is just one. Ausmelt were involved in others. That part of chapter 6 is well worth reading. The committee is not convinced there is a pressing need for Australia's development assistance program to become more trade focused than it already is. We think that it has a good balance, but we do not want to see the CFF program reduced, diminished or changed. We also noted that, of the 1994-95 program budget to AusAID, which totalled $98 million, over half, $58 million, was designated for CFF projects which would assist Australian companies.

We are gravely concerned that the government has reported that it intends to cut this program because in doing this report we were given first-hand evidence of the value of this program in two ways. It is of value to the Australian companies who use the program to provide assistance to a country and then follow up with follow-on projects, and it is of value so far as the development of a country that receives that assistance is concerned. I urge members of the Senate and everyone to very carefully read and digest this section and to wholeheartedly support recommendation 7.

Once again, I take this opportunity to thank everybody who has been involved with the project and this committee report. It has been one of the most enjoyable and fulfilling ones I think I have ever undertaken. We went to China in April 1994, and in September of last year I had a chance to visit China again for the women's conference. It was interesting to see how much less restriction there was and how much freer the area around Beijing was 18 months later.

We had the opportunity in September of last year to move freely around Beijing, to use the taxis and the private and public sector transport systems, and to experience, I suppose, part of the traffic problems now being inflicted upon not just Shanghai, which we experienced when we were there in April 1994, but also Beijing. I have a great love for the country and look forward to being able to return to see what is happening.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering items 1 and 2 of schedule 1 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1996. The question is that the items stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we adjourned the debate, I was indicating the Greens' support for the objection to these two items in the schedule, which the opposition and Australian Democrats have already spoken about. I was pointing out at the time progress was reported that there is support—I am sure the government is aware of it—for the abolition of ATSIC and an administrator being put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that that by any means should be taken as support for the amendment that the government has here. I was going to read a letter by way of example, but unfortunately I will have to refer to it from memory because I have folded my papers away. Our office received some phone calls and at least one letter where people asked, `Why are you supporting ATSIC when ATSIC has been very deficient in reaching out to a lot of communities across Australia? Wouldn't it be better to abolish it and put an administrator in charge?'

I said, `What would you want to do that for?' They said, `So we could get better service delivery.' I said, `What would you think if the administrator was put in place to make sure that the accountability mechanisms and the bureaucratic mechanisms of ATSIC were strengthened and entrenched?' They were horrified to hear this because that is the very problem. They think there is already so many bureaucratic mechanisms in place that the direct service delivery of ATSIC and the direct funding are being interfered with.

So a lot of the support that the government may be receiving for these measures should be, at least on my hypothesis, investigated to see whether what people had in mind under these amendments is exactly what would happen. SPEECH.PARA: In completing my earlier comments, I would like to say that the people who do not like this amendment do not like it because they see it as being aimed at the abolition of ATSIC. Those who express support for it as an amendment think that this is the proposal by the government; they think it might be good to abolish ATSIC. I want to put on the record that I do not think it will actually abolish ATSIC. What I think it will do is put an enormous threat on ATSIC which will make it almost impossible for it to improve its functioning. I feel, if there is to be any question of the abolition of ATSIC, that the only legitimate way to do it would be for this government to have a proposal for something far better in its place that had the support of the majority of Aboriginal people right across the community. That is the reason the Democrats, with the Labor Party and the Greens, are opposing these two items of the schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before responding, I will answer Senator Collins's question. The board is not sacked; they remain in office, and their powers will resume after the administrator ceases. That is the first point. Secondly, my understanding is it would be major fraud involving the commissioners, and this understanding was reflected in my second reading speech. That is, only in exceptional circumstances would that be invoked.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Chamarette's question, I inform the chamber that there was no intention whatsoever in our policy to get rid of ATSIC. That was stated quite clearly in our policy and I have restated it on a number of occasions since. The clause related purely to accountability and the sanction that could apply if these extraordinary circumstances should occur. As I mentioned last Friday, perhaps something should have been inserted right at the beginning in the ATSIC Act. I am not sure that it was even discussed. Senator Bob Collins said it was not brought up at any stage because of the concern about self‐management.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, because there were very many layers of accountability in the bill as a result of 200 amendments.
—I said that it was canvassed at length.
—Did you? But I think it was not proceeded with.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not saying it is deliberate, but I think that this matter has been misrepresented. I do not think that Senator Herron heard what was said last Friday and today. The reason such a provision was not incorporated in the original ATSIC Bill was that, after a couple of hundred amendments and extremely long debate, many layers of accountability were already imposed and it was not deemed necessary. That is why such a provision is not there; it was not deemed by the majority of the parliament to be necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I defer to my learned friend Senator Cooney, I will chase this rabbit all the way down the burrow just to satisfy myself, because the law may well have moved on from the last time a mug like me looked at it. The minister made reference to his second reading speech. My understanding, the last time I looked, or the last time I talked to a judge, is that a court will take account of second reading speeches only when it needs to be guided on the provisions of the law. If a court is absolutely satisfied that the law as printed is clear, the second reading speech of the minister is just so much paper. Perhaps that practice has changed. Courts these days are finding implied rights for freedom of speech in the constitution which I cannot find, so they are more inventive than I am.

SPEECH.PARA: I take your point, Minister, that we are not talking about sacking the board, but we certainly are talking about disabling it for the period that the administrator is in office. For that reason, this provision concerns me. I will put an extreme hypothetical case of a fraud that has occurred in a regional office of ATSIC. It is beyond dispute that fraud has occurred. It involves, say, a million dollars, which triggers the minister's requirement to be satisfied. I guess it is a matter for political or moral judgment as to whether it is major fraud; nevertheless, fraud has occurred and the minister has acted lawfully by appointing an administrator.

In respect of an appeal to the judicial review process, surely it would be very difficult to get a court to overturn that decision, even if, on the reasonable judgment of somebody standing outside the process, the matter were confined to one office and not systemic in the organisation. Providing a fraud had occurred and the proposed provision complied with—there is no reference in this provision to `major' or `extreme' fraud—the legislation is satisfied. If you have satisfied the act, is it not very difficult to get any court to go beyond the decision of the minister and overturn it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that my advisers are making is that I may appoint an administrator; I do not have to. Senator Collins is correct in the point he made about second reading speeches. I am advised that the provision clearly relates to fraud on the part of the board. If there be any ambiguity, my speech would resolve it. The particular circumstances would determine the case but if fraud has occurred, the answer to your question is: probably not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two things I would like to check. Proposed new section 78B(1) of the act states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If the Minister is satisfied that:
(a) the administration by the Commission of the Commission's money has involved fraud or gross mismanagement . . .

Doesn't that mean that no elected commissioner need necessarily be guilty of fraud or gross mismanagement, but, if an appointed officer, whether paid or not, commits fraud, that would be sufficient—it does not have to be criminal fraud, as you say; just fraud—to trigger 78B.

As you say, it does not lead to the dismissal of the commission, but it leads to the appointment of a commission administrator for up to 18 months. If during that 18 months the commission administrator committed a fraud, gross misconduct or gross mismanagement, could that not, under proposed new section 78C(2), be attributed to the commission itself, and the commission itself could therefore be given another 18 months out of office? So the appointment of a commission administrator who turned out to be fraudulent could cost the commission a further period out of office because 78C(2) clearly states:
. . . the Commission Administrator is taken to be acting as the Commission's agent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I am advised that the fraud has to be by the commission, and the commission, in turn, is defined as the board.
—It does not say that at all. It does not say `if the minister is satisfied that the commission has committed fraud'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If the Minister is satisfied that:

PARA.TAB: (a) the administration by the Commission of the Commission's money has involved fraud or gross mismanagement . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The administration of the Senate is not carried out by the Senate; it is carried out by Mr Harry Evans and his outstanding staff. That is what you mean by administration. It is true that it is carried out at the behest of the Senate. I think that you would find that to say that section 78B means that it has to be done by the commission would be a fairly tortured reading of the section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I reiterate that the words in proposed new section 78B(1) say, as you quite correctly pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the administration by the Commission of the Commission's money . . .

It is understood that the commission is the board, as I said. But it is also true to say that, apparently, through the act there is some ambiguity in the sense that the words are interchanged in the act itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —But is there any ambiguity?

—They are used, apparently, as I am advised, interchangeably. In reply to the other question which you asked previously, the answer is no. There is an 18‐month time limit, even if there is a second or even a third administrator appointed, and that is referred to under 78B(3).

—You are given, as it were, 18 months in respect of a finding by the minister of a commission of a fraud or gross mismanagement by the administration of the commission. That clearly is in respect of a particular fraud or a particular mismanagement. If another fraud or another mismanagement takes place later down the line, say six or seven months down the line, then surely proposed new section 78B is triggered again; otherwise the provision would not make sense. If proposed new section 78C(2) has any meaning, what meaning do you give to it? If the commission administrator commits a fraud, he or she does so as the commission's agent. It clearly says that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I am advised that, for whatever reason the administrator may be in place, there is a maximum of 18 months. For whatever reason, it is still a maximum of 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.
Item 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I am standing here with the list of amendments that have been circulated in the name of the Greens (WA). I am looking at item 1, which is not an amendment, but is rather the proposition that we oppose item 3 of schedule 1. This is the item that provides for the reduction in the number of councillors by the population formula contained in the act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens oppose this item on the basis that there has been no argument put forward to suggest that the new formula will be better than the old, nor has there been any demonstration that the new figures have some compelling argument in their favour. I will not speak any more, but simply indicate our opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —To save the time of the Senate, could I just indicate that I will deal with all of the amendments on this schedule when I speak. We will be supporting the first amendment by the Greens (WA). I think it was clear from the second reading debate that that would be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: For Senator Chamarette's benefit, I indicate that we will not be supporting the other amendments on the schedule, although we have of course, as you are aware, circulated our own amendments. I will wait until the appropriate time during the committee stage to explain my reasons for that. We will be supporting the opposition to this section and we will not be supporting amendments 2 to 6.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting the Greens' actions. I agree with Senator Chamarette's comments that no compelling case has yet been made for what it will do to the notion of `representativeness'. We should note that this came out of the ATSIC review. We should also note that many regional councillors oppose what was contained in the ATSIC review. All of the witnesses who spoke to us from the regional councils at the committee hearing last Friday similarly opposed the government's intentions in this respect. One of those councils had in their paper a possible compromise and went on to say, `But we don't want to make this compromise.' But we have all been talking about the need for a review and I think it is really important that we do that before we proceed with this matter at all. It should be left the same until then.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Schedule 1, page 4 (after line 11), after item 4, insert:
Repeal the subsections, substitute:

(2) Subject to subsection (3), a person is not qualified to be appointed as a Commissioner if he or she has been convicted and is under sentence, or subject to be sentenced, for any offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory by imprisonment for one year or longer.

(3) Subsection (2) does not disqualify a person from being appointed as a Commissioner if the Federal Court of Australia, on application by the person, declares that in spite of the person's conviction, he or she ought not to be disqualified from being appointed as a Commissioner.
5. Schedule 1, page 7 (after line 12), after item 15, insert:
Repeal the paragraphs, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (a) has been convicted and is under sentence, or subject to be sentenced, for any offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory by imprisonment for one year or longer;

SPEECH.PARA: 7. Schedule 1, page 13 (after line 3), after item 28, insert:
Repeal the paragraphs, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (d) the person has been convicted and is under sentence, or subject to be sentenced, for any offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory by imprisonment for one year or longer;

SPEECH.PARA: 10. Schedule 1, item 34, page 14 (line 25) to page 15 (line 8), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the paragraphs, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (a) has been convicted and is under sentence, or subject to be sentenced, for any offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory by imprisonment for one year or longer;

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments are to repeal the subsections and substitute the clauses as circulated to the committee which will, presuming the committee supports the amendments, then read:

Subject to subsection (3), a person is not qualified to be appointed as a Commissioner if he or she has been convicted and is under sentence, or subject to be sentenced, for any offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory by imprisonment for one year or longer.

All honourable senators will be very familiar with those provisions—because they do, in fact, apply to us. They must be fairly common around the Commonwealth of Australia. They certainly were the provisions that applied when I was a member of the Northern Territory parliament.

Importantly, the committee should note that it is not a question of being actually sentenced to 12 months that triggers this disqualification. It is being convicted of an offence which is punishable by a sentence of 12 months or longer. I do not resile from the fact that, in that sense, it is a tough provision. It is an appropriate condition that is certainly placed on the tenure of members of parliament, and it is not unreasonable to have it placed on members of the ATSIC board. Paragraph (3) reads:

Subsection (2) does not disqualify a person from being appointed as a Commissioner if the Federal Court of Australia, on application by the person, declares that in spite of the person's conviction, he or she ought not to be disqualified from being appointed as a Commissioner.

It simply, explicitly, puts in there that there will be a check and balance—there will be an opportunity for the person to have their day in court if they feel they have been unfairly dealt with. But it is, in my respectful submission, a tougher provision than the one proposed and, in that sense, should be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Bob Collins. He did not mention part 3. But I think it is important that we have the same rules that apply to us; and, secondly, it is important that there is an appeal provision—and that is why we will be supporting it.
—I did mention part 3.
—I am sorry, I missed you, I beg your pardon.
—We will be supporting the amendments that Senator Bob Collins has proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept that the eligibility and termination provisions of the act should be watered down. These aspects were part of the original legislation and no case for a change has been presented.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions are designed to ensure that appropriate people are elected to the responsible positions of commissioner and regional councillor. This not only aids accountability but also protects the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities who rely on ATSIC for the provision of services and programs.
ATSIC is a Commonwealth statutory authority and, as such, its office‐bearers should be subject to stringent eligibility and termination requirements and, therefore, we will be opposing the amendment.
Amendments agreed to.
Schedule 1, item 14.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment we are opposing removes the requirement for the minister to consult with the commission before suspending a commissioner. Before I speak on this, I would be interested in hearing the minister's explanation for why he is doing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is supported by the board, on the grounds that the decision is the responsibility of the minister. They asked for it to be in and I am happy to support that.

—I am aware that that was the reason you gave in the committee hearing. I was interested to know whether you had any ministerial view on the issue. I do not want to suggest for a minute that I think that everything that flows from ATSIC is writ in stone. We have clearly indicated that by the fact that we have opposed the reduction in the number of councillors. However, as the minister acknowledged, I did say in the debate and I say again now that I think that at the end of the day, as far as the Labor Party is concerned, we will not end up too far away from each other. I am aware that this is a recommendation of ATSIC but I was curious as to whether the minister had a view, independent of ATSIC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for the question. I went through this process in making a determination in recent times. My view is that it is a very onerous responsibility on the minister to make such a determination. It is even more onerous for the board to make such a determination because of the difficulties for the board in making such a determination on one of their own members, as would occur in any group or board in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is the reason the board wishes to stay as it is. Having just gone through that process, I consider it to be the minister's responsibility to consult with the board before making that determination. Quite rightly, it is a responsibility of the minister. In turn, it protects the board members from being put in the position of having to make a determination on a fellow member of the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may have misheard what the minister just said as to who makes the determination. I was not suggesting that we were putting the commission at any stage in the place of the minister or in having some determinative role to play. The section that we would want to leave is simply the section that deals with consulting the commission. Independent of any view the ATSIC board may have, if a minister takes what, I am sure, would be a regrettable and extreme step in removing a commissioner, it is not unreasonable to provide for this provision. I might add that I am encouraged to hear what the minister has said, that it is his view that such consultation would be appropriate. There is probably, therefore, no need to delay the chamber longer as I am sure the minister is not going to fall in a heap if this provision is retained in the act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wondered whether there might be some extenuating circumstances that are relevant to your decision that might make it more profitable for you to consult, Minister? What does `consult' mean to you? I understand the point you made; I think it is valid. But on the other side you could say that you could profit from having the opportunity to have some level of consultation with the board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context, Senator Kernot, while all the facts may be on paper, it is important that there be consultation with the board to hear anything verbally that may not have been in the strict letter of the law. While accepting the responsibility, I think it is incumbent on the minister to listen to any advice that is given by the individual members of the board and the whole board to clear up before the board any items that may be in dispute regarding the facts, to give the board the opportunity to advise the minister in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Hopefully, that clarifies what you are asking. On the one hand there is a responsibility to consult with the board in reaching a determination and, on the other hand, it is the responsibility of the minister to make a decision after that consultation, certainly not before. I believe that is why the board wishes to retain that in the bill and, certainly, is why I support it. Having gone through the process recently, I believe it is a very correct process and it should stay in, as it is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying the opposite? Are you saying that you would prefer to be required to consult rather than just give written notice of why a commissioner should show cause as to why he or she should not be suspended? Are you saying that you would prefer to be required to consult?
—Yes.
—Okay, well I am going to help you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked for a personal opinion, and I gave it. That is so, but I have indicated already that I will be opposing this amendment. That was an aside in relation to it.

—If the government's amendment to the act is carried so that the minister is not compelled to consult the commission, would it nevertheless be open to either House of Parliament under section 40(4) to require the minister to do so before attending to the matter on a resolution?
—Would you be kind enough to repeat the question.

—As section 40 now stands, the minister has to consult the commission. If section 40(2)(b) were deleted, would it nevertheless be open to either House of Parliament to require the minister to consult the commission before it dealt with the issue by resolution under section 40(4)?
—Yes. That is so. It is a disallowable instrument, so it would be open to either house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —IWe are opposing these provisions. They are the heart of the bill in respect of all the provisions for the appointment of an administrator to the commission. I have certainly gone over in some length the reasons for the opposition not supporting these provisions. I take this opportunity to again make it absolutely clear that we are as one with the government, the Greens, the Australian Democrats and everybody else about the need for the strictest requirements of accountability in respect of ATSIC as an association.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the point I am about to make has been made by other senators. These points were made by me in the committee, but I also want to make them here. There is one thing I find objectionable about these provisions and the appointment of the special auditor. These two things are related, as the minister knows full well; we discussed this at some length in the committee when we were discussing the provisions of this bill on Friday.

I heard evidence on Friday and I have heard an enormous amount of evidence over the last few days. I was also faxed this afternoon by a lawyer in Darwin the minutes of a meeting held in Darwin to deal with social security matters. That meeting dealt with the effect that the appointment of a special auditor would have on the operations of ATSIC bodies right across Australia. As a result of all this evidence, I am far from satisfied that sufficient attention was given to this matter by the government and the minister, although I concede that it may well have been out of his hands. I was a member of cabinet and government for quite a number of years. Nevertheless, the minister is responsible both in a real sense and in here for the legislation that goes through in respect of Aboriginal affairs.

One thing that provides for that concern is the sheer timing of these proposals, the appointment of the special auditor and the minister's own evidence to the committee last Friday. I am sure that he can recall it. That evidence is that he was aware of ATSIC's concerns about having gone through all this accountability stuff which would eventually lead, in the worst possible case, to the appointment of an administrator to replace the board. He had heard from the commissioner as to their concerns about the lack of action that subsequently followed references from the Fraud Awareness Unit after investigations by the Office of Evaluation and Audit. I think I am accurately paraphrasing his words. He had attempted to pursue this matter and had been unable to get a clear answer as to why none of this had happened.

The concerns I had that the simple physical lapse of time did not allow for it were fairly firmly set in place by the minister's own words. I said last Friday that I felt that, rather than putting out press releases accusing other people of being negligent, the minister and, in a corporate sense, the government were negligent in simply saying, `Can't give you a satisfactory answer to that,' and then rushing off to a press conference to announce that the only solution was to have an administrator, for the administrator to be able to disable the entire board for fraud—it is all up in lights; we are going to make it squeaky clean again—and to appoint a special auditor.

In respect of the special auditor, I can tell the minister right here and now, because of the correspondence I have had in the last hour, confusion still reigns supreme. While the lawyers are here—and the appointment of the administrator and the appointment of the special auditor are related, as we acknowledged last Friday—perhaps the minister can explain something that puzzles me.

The minister issued directions, which I as a non-lawyer have read, to the board under section 12 of this act rather than under the other section—I think it is section 74, from memory—that enables the minister to issue directions in respect of financial matters to the board. The first paragraph of those directions to the board says, from memory—and stop me when I am wrong—that `you will not disburse any further money to anybody until you get a certificate from the special auditor' or words to that effect, and there is a three-week time lapse.

My understanding of that as a non-lawyer is that the clock takes over completely at that point. This may be something the minister can clarify now. My understanding of that provision, in respect of having a clean‐up for fraud, is that if the special auditor fails to complete the audit in the first paragraph of the minister's direction within the allotted three weeks, the audit is simply not completed. The adviser is nodding her assent—thank you. They are all nodding their heads; I must be on a winner here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too right; you're on a winner!

—I am on the home straight. Thank you, Minister, I don't mean to trouble you with it. It is then open to ATSIC to go ahead with the grant. I assume that has been put in there for the very proper reason that the government did not want the affairs of ATSIC to be disabled for an inordinate period of time.

SPEECH.PARA: But—and this is the point I wanted cleared up now and this is a little more complicated—in the instructions for the special auditor, which I have also read and they were widely circulated, there is a reference to a short‐cut audit for organisations that might need a bit of help to get them across the line. The reason I am asking the question—and I am sure it is obvious to the advisers—is that this is where the problem has occurred, if it has occurred, with the letter that was sent from the ATSIC office.

From my own non-legal reading of the ATSIC letter, that ATSIC letter seemed to be a totally accurate reflection of the black-letter provisions that I had read in your directions and in the instruction manual that was issued. The instruction manual did have a section in it dealing with an expedited process for the audit—if you like, a quick audit, a preliminary audit—but, nevertheless, the audit, as preliminary as it might be, had to be done; it could not simply be circumvented.
