That was consistent with what was contained in the letter from the ATSIC office.

There might be a brilliant opportunity here to clear up this entire confusion for everybody's sake. They are listening to what we are saying at the moment. There might not be a whole heap of them, but I know at least 10 or 15 people are listening. Do you understand the problem, Minister? The instructions talk about an expedited audit, but the audit, nevertheless, has to happen.

I also noted in another section that the minister also has an overriding power under certain circumstances to step in himself, which is probably what this association in Western Australia was hoping he would do. But the understanding on the ground at the ATSIC regional level is that, before this expedited process can be triggered, there has to be at least a clearance, however quick it is, by the special auditor before they are empowered to issue one dollar of funds.

Minister, you do have an opportunity now to clear this up for once and for all. I am assured by everybody that I have spoken to that their interpretation of what they have been given—and they have been given the minister's direction and the instruction manual—is that, fundamentally, the content of that letter is accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, were you referring to Miss O'Donoghue's letter?
—No, sorry, Minister. I thought I had made that clear. The letter I was referring to was the letter from the Kimberley ATSIC office. Let me tell you fundamentally what the letter said.
—I am aware of it.

—But the advisers clearly are not; they are shaking their heads now. The letter said—and I will get you one, if I can—that the Junjuwa association said to the regional office of ATSIC, `The minister's adviser has told us that, if we are squeaky clean and we have been cleared by an audit—and, indeed, we have; the last audit we had gave us a tick—then we do not have a problem.' I said that today in question time, as the minister would recall.

SPEECH.PARA: They relayed that back to the ATSIC office and the ATSIC office said—I believe in good faith—`That may well be so, but that is not what we have got in front of us here. What we have got in front of us here is the instruction manual and the minister's direction.' They would also have had advice from head office I would strongly suspect.

I know quite a number of ATSIC bureaucrats, and I think the particular individual is quite a senior one. I do not know him personally, but I understand he is from the Perth head office and he is there temporarily because of the problem the minister alluded to the other day. He no doubt—knowing good bureaucrats—would have checked that with someone higher up the line.

He said to Junjuwa, `Yes, there are expedited processes, but they cannot even be triggered until the special auditor has given, under the instruction manual, the quick clearance which we are all hoping will be given. I cannot give you an offer until at least that happens. There is nothing, consistent with the minister's directions that empowers me to do that.'

Where I am getting to legally, and I am only a bush lawyer, is that it is seems to me that unless there is a piece of paper that allows you to simply hand out $300,000, that action would be utterly in breach of the first paragraph of your directions. Where is that piece of paper? I am sure it must exist. Where is the qualification for the first paragraph of your ministerial direction which allows this quick action to be taken and for someone to be given a cheque for $300,000 and go off to the races. Nobody in ATSIC seems to be aware of how it will be done. Do you now understand the problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would very much like to clear up any confusion. I appreciate that there is confusion because you have been pursuing this for some time. I thank you for also pointing out that we are being broadcast and that there are 15 to 20 people listening—I hope there are many more as a result of your intervention.
—You will now give the definitive answer.

—I will give you the definitive answer. There are numerous examples of services essential to indigenous communities which are provided by organisations funded under ATSIC or TSRA programs such as water provisions, sewerage and drainage services, electricity provisions and employment. Often CDEP is the sole source of community income, as you well know. Because of that, strengthened accountability is even more important for basic services such as these.

BREAK.PARA: The transitional arrangements provide for essential services, without a history of significant breaches, to be funded immediately. The government expects that ATSIC or TSRA will only propose grants to organisations that are fit and proper. I am sure you would support that. The minister will not be disposed to allow grants or loans to bodies not fit and proper except in the most exceptional circumstances and where a satisfactory ratification strategy is in place.

Relevant exceptional circumstances may be where, for instance, an organisation provides essential services where there is no alternative provider and where substantial restructuring of the organisation, together with an administrator or grant controller, is agreed. The major focus should remain on the bona fides of the organisation concerned and whether sufficient remedial action to develop an alternate provider or to rectify the providers organisational problems have been put in place by ATSIC or TSRA.

I do not believe that any Australian, indigenous or otherwise, would want ATSIC or TSRA to make grants to organisations found not fit and proper to receive public moneys. The major emphasis is on bringing poorly performing organisations up to speed or developing alternative providers who will be accountable.

In regard to those transitional arrangements, in order to minimise the possibility of delay in the payment of grants or loans to organisations which are not in breach of grants conditions, the government decided that transitional arrangements should be put in place to speed up the decisions relating to lower risk organisations. These arrangements provide that those organisations categorised by ATSIC or TSRA as having no current breach of grant conditions and no other significantly adverse history will not be required to be scrutinised by the special auditor for their July grants. I think that clarifies it completely.

The relevant financial information will still need to be provided and the organisation will be subject to special auditor scrutiny by 1 October 1996 and will be provided funds pro rata up to a limit of $300,000 per grant or loan. In other words, those organisations which have abided by the accountability requirements in the past should be under no risk of any delays in their upcoming grants. That is what I referred to in question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is simply a need for one clarification in respect of that helpful statement. You appeared to make an absolute qualification at the beginning of that explanation that this related to essential services. It is a fact that many communities use CDEP moneys for these essential services. The question that is still outstanding, if I heard you correctly, is: what happens to CDEPs that are not involved in the provision of essential services?
—The transitional arrangements apply to all organisations and not just to essential services.
—So that qualification is not there?
—No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made my remarks about why the Democrats think the reserve power to appoint an administrator is discriminatory so I will not repeat them. I do not think we have put on the record yet what was pointed out to us in the committee hearing. Some 95 per cent of the organisations funded by ATSIC have no problems acquitting grant moneys. Of the remaining five per cent, the majority of the problems are due to inexperience or mismanagement. A few of the five per cent are due to deliberate actions. ATSIC acts on those and has referred them on. We have talked about the level of resourcing and the priority of those agencies to whom they are referred. You do not need to appoint an administrator. You need to do something about the mechanisms that already exist.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet, I would like to commend whoever was responsible for the layout of this bill. I think it is the clearest and easiest bill I have ever had to read. Whoever chose the typeface and so on—well done.
Schedule 1, item 19 negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: 8. Schedule 1, page 13 (after line 6), after item 29, insert:
Repeal the subsection, substitute:

(2) In spite of subsection (1), a person covered by paragraph (1) (d) is not disqualified by that paragraph from standing for election, or being elected, as a member of a Regional Council if the Federal Court of Australia, on application by the person, declares that in spite of the person's conviction, he or she ought not to be disqualified from standing for election, or being elected, as a member of a Regional Council.
This amendment is very simple. It retains the Federal Court appeal for regional council eligibility.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9. Schedule 1, item 30, page 13 (lines 8 to 15), omit the item.
This, again—and there are a number of these—is simply done to be consistent with the removal of the horned beast.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 11. Schedule 1, after item 43, page 21 (after line 8), insert:
Add:

(6) A report to the minister under subsection (3) in respect of the first Regional Council elections conducted after 1 July 1996 must include an examination of ways in which the representation of distinct community groups on Regional Councils could be accommodated.

This provision was discussed, I think, at some length last Friday during the committee hearing. It requires section 141, which deals with the review process, to have a look at a more intelligent way of improving regional council representation. As I have said in a number of contributions to the debate so far, I do not think that at the end of the day we are far removed in respect of getting agreement on these matters.

Having said that, I am persuaded by individual representations I have had, and indeed evidence that was given to our committee last Friday, that there are still around the edges some problems in respect of the Realpolitik on the ground in these regions, which, if they are sensibly addressed, will lead to a much better organisation for ATSIC at the end of the day. This gives effect to that desire to actually have this requirement written into the act. Indeed, from memory, I can recall that Senator Chamarette—maybe it was Senator Kernot—addressed this same issue last Friday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject the inference that representation of distinct community groups is necessary in the interests of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities as a whole. We could go ad absurdum if you so wish.
—Say that again.

—If you are inferring that representation of distinct community groups is necessary in the interests of the community as a whole—and that is what your amendment says—I reject that. Community groups and interests can be and are adequately represented through the present electoral process. It has been in existence for six years. It is fundamental to the operation of regional councils that councillors seek to represent the interests of the whole region, not particular communities or interest groups.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to that. I think what regional councillors have been careful to point out to us is this: no matter how the zone is arranged, or how the region is geographically arranged, the fact of the matter is that people live in different parts of it, and are mobile and may be enrolled elsewhere anyway. It is the notion of maintaining representation, particularly for those who live in remote areas, and the possibility that, under a reduction in size, it could well be that concentration of population means that some areas are unrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what we are saying we have to take time to sort out so that we get this balance right. We represent quite distinct interests and population dispersions to some extent, too, in this Senate. That is what we are saying, `Let's get it right for Aboriginal people.' It is Aboriginal communities—plural with a small `c'—Senator Herron, which is quite different from the community at large.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12. Schedule 1, item 45, page 21 (line 22) to page 22 (line 4), omit the item.
13. Schedule 1, item 46, page 22 (line 5) to page 26 (line 5), omit the item.
They, again, are consequential upon everything that we have said to this point in time. Amendment 13, of course, simply applies the same removal to the Torres Strait as to ATSIC.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: No. 1 Schedule 1, item 48, page 26 (line 23), omit "Imprisonment for 1 year", substitute "50 penalty units".
No. 2 Schedule 1, item 50, page 27 (line 25), omit "Imprisonment for 5 years", substitute "200 penalty units".
No. 3 Schedule 1, item 52, page 28 (lines 2 to 3), omit "imprisonment for not more than 6 months", substitute "a fine not exceeding 25 penalty units".
No. 4 Schedule 1, item 55, page 28 (line 14), omit "Imprisonment for 6 months", substitute "25 penalty units".
No. 5 Schedule 1, item 55, page 28 (line 18), omit "Imprisonment for 6 months", substitute "25 penalty units".

I will speak to the amendments together and they can be voted on separately. They all relate to removing references to prison penalties within the act and substituting the appropriate penalty units. There is no diminution in the range of discretion that is given, but there is a principle being applied and, as many senators will be well aware, this is consistent with a campaign that I have been conducting in relation to the Social Security Act and also in any other bills that come to my attention.

The reason for that is to support the principle that prison should be a penalty of last resort, and that our commitment to that principle should not be simply nominal. In particular, I believe that we have a case in point, that the offences here are serious ones. There is no question about that. But the question as to what is the most appropriate penalty can be answered with almost complete certainty that prison should not be used as a first resort, which is what is implied, and it has been stated in this way in the act.

It should be up to the court to determine the appropriate penalties. To have penalty units means that there is a range of sanctions and penalties that the court can apply. We should be particularly concerned about this when discussing the ATSIC bills, because recommendation No. 92 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody strongly urges that imprisonment be applied only as a penalty of last resort. I believe we need to have a much stronger response in the area of Aboriginal over‐representation in prison. We need to look at the way in which prison is used in a coercive and threatening way if we are going to keep putting it as though it has a deterrent effect when criminologists know that that is not the case.

I believe that it would be beneficial to remove the reference to imprisonment and put the penalty unit equivalents in support of that principle that we should not be implying prison has some kind of magic value by being mentioned in the act. We should certainly be supporting the idea that the penalty should fit the crime and the offence, and that should be left up to the appropriate court determination. That is why I would urge my colleagues to support these amendments. I already know that I am unlikely to get that support, but I want to just put that on the record.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support amendments 2, 5 and 6 because they deal with the crime of divulging information or giving false or misleading information about the right to vote in an election. I do not think imprisonment is at all appropriate for that. However, for amendments 3 and 4, which relate to making false or misleading statements in relation to guarantees or loans, it would be more appropriate for the magistrate to have a choice of penalty units or a sentence. That is why, regretfully, I cannot support amendments 3 and 4. If the Labor Party's amendments are carried, I hope there will be a choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to clarify my position. I understand what Senator Kernot is saying, but my understanding is that using the term `penalty units' does not preclude a prison penalty being given. It actually allows either a prison penalty of the same amount that is in the act or a fine. In my view it takes that connotation of imprisonment as a threat of first resort out of the bill. So to my knowledge it does not change the penalties which may be applied or the discretion that is available to the court. Instead, it starts to produce a climate committed to removing prison as a threat which we have been using over the Aboriginal community for 200 years. That is the reason why I would like to see the measure removed.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish it could remove the capacity to imprison people as readily as we do, but it does not do that. It is very nominal in that sense, and in a way it is tokenistic. I would rather say that it is symbolic than tokenistic, because I believe it is time that we started addressing the way in which imprisonment is used in this society. As Senator Kernot has pointed out, for offences concerning voting—or, in my belief, even if it is a serious offence—imprisonment is a penalty that should be used to protect the community from danger or to protect an individual from being a danger to himself or herself. It is not to be used simply as a first option in order to enforce a particular discipline. There are many appropriate penalties that may be applied, but we do not exercise them if we can so quickly resort to prison.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support completely Senator Chamarette's support for the Aboriginal deaths in custody recommendation that prison should be a last resort. The difficulty I have with her amendments is that they produce a situation where imprisonment is no resort at all.
—That's not correct.

—That is the reason I am rising: I want to get this absolute ly clear. I would like some clarification from Senator Chamarette because I might be wrong. From reading Senator Chamarette's amendment schedule, it appears to have the effect of removing any penalty of imprisonment completely and substituting fines only. Perhaps I have misread it, but that is the effect that I believe it has.

—I would like to put on the record what my understanding is. I would be glad to be told if I am wrong because I would not want to place an error into the system. My understanding is that simply substituting `50 penalty units' for the term `imprisonment for one year' does not preclude a court from determining a penalty of imprisonment for one year or a fine. If it could be so easily removed and the court could be told of that, I would be delighted. I would also understand why I have never received support for the amendments I have proposed of this kind. My understanding is that it is simply removing it from the legislation and not from the discretion of the court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My interpretation was the same as Senator Collins's, but I have consulted the lawyers here and they are going out to check that our interpretation is correct. Certainly, on face value that was the original interpretation. As Senator Chamarette has a different view, and as she is probably more experienced than any of us in this chamber in relation to prisons and courts from a previous occupation, we will accept her statement and check the interpretation for her. We have another lawyer here in the chamber who might have another interpretation, but we will certainly check it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said on many occasions publicly—this might encourage Senator Chamarette—that one of the things I actually find stimulating about the Senate, and I meant this when I said it, is that it is one of the few houses of parliament I have been associated with around the place where I have actually seen over the years the course of a debate change the outcome. In other words, what happens in this chamber has actually affected the result. I have seen that in here on many occasions, and this is one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: I advise Senator Kernot that she has won me, and therefore Senator Chamarette has partially won me as well. We will now support Senator Chamarette, as the Democrats will, in relation to amendments Nos 2, 5 and 6, but we will press our amendments Nos 15 and 16, which relate to—correct me if I am wrong—the same sections that Nos 3 and 4 on Senator Chamarette's schedule would have dealt with. We supported No. 1. So far as the opposition is concerned, Senator Chamarette has four out of six, which ain't bad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) will allow me to speak for a couple of minutes, since I chaired last Friday the meeting of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee when it inquired into the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill. On Friday I was very interested to hear Senator Chamarette use, in relation to imprisonment, the rationale of the Aboriginal deaths in custody report. From where I stand and from where any Aboriginal community or organisation stands, the line that Senator Chamarette has taken is that all corruption or misdemeanours that finish up in court will have been committed by Aboriginal people. Senator Chamarette should think about that again.

SPEECH.PARA: When I have asked in this place for an inquiry into ATSIC and ATSIC related bodies in Western Australia, I have always said that my worry is—and Senator Kernot had the chance to support me in August 1993—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got a memory like an elephant.

—Yes, I have a good memory. My worry then, and it still is, is that, as cases evolve in the courts in Western Australia in years to come, we will find out it was not the Aboriginal community that was guilty of some of that corruption but it was what I call the white Aboriginal industry—in other words, those who managed funds and so on. I have to put on the record that the ration ale Senator Chamarette is talking about implies that it is only Aboriginal people who commit this crime. If there was a white administrator, tell me the situation regarding imprisonment would be the same as if the administrator were Aboriginal.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make relates to the use of penalty points that presumably end up with a fine. In a previous life I had a bit to do with sentencing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not on the receiving end!

—No, not on the receiving end. Senator Cooney will know that one of the principles of sentencing is that you should not fine people by an amount that will end up with them going to prison. In other words, the fine should not be so high that they will not be able to afford to pay it and have to go to prison instead. For fine defaults people are imprisoned for certain amounts of time. We have to look at that angle as well. Using penalty points is not necessarily the end of the matter at all. Having chaired that meeting and listened to Senator Chamarette and this debate, I thought I would put my thoughts on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza for doing that because it is a helpful way of clarifying what I am saying. I do note that we raised this matter at the committee and it was the minister's response that, because this could as easily apply to non‐Aboriginal people as Aboriginal people, he did not feel that the recommendation in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody was relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: My point stands because it does not matter who is subject to the penalty, whether it be an Aboriginal person or a non-Aboriginal person. I would not want to discriminate. My point is that the punishment should fit the crime and that it is very rare that the punishment of imprisonment actually fits the crime. It has become one of those, I believe, easy recourses that we have used over the years to punish people inappropriately when we could think creatively of better ways of making restitution, such as by counselling, community service and other approaches to restore the community, rather than increasing the damage by the very costly—socially, humanly and economically—measure of imprisonment. So my point still stands.

I have been using this argument in relation to the Social Security Act where it is again of no relevance. I think I raised this measure in relation to a disabilities work supplement allowance where a disabled person was penalised by a prison penalty for failure to give accurate information. I pointed out how ridiculous it was to have even mentioned in legislation of that kind those kinds of draconian penalties because, if there is serious fraud, the Crimes Act is referred to. Prison penalties are within the Crimes Act. So I do not believe that it is necessary to fill this legislation, which is dealing with much less serious crimes and offences, with the same kind of prison terminology as though we were recreating another crimes act.

I could be in error. I will have to plead feebleness of the brain or something in the last two days of the session if I am in error. My understanding was that the ease of converting one year of imprisonment into 50 penalty units was simply that—that it did not take away that possibility. But I could be wrong and I will seek the guidance of the chamber. In any event I would welcome support from Senator Bob Collins and the Democrats if they were prepared to support at least amendments Nos 2, 5 and 6, on the basis that those amendments are very minor and would not even deserve imprisonment provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to explain to the minister why I am interested in pursuing this matter. I make no bones about it; it is fundamentally for my continuing education and that of all other legislators. We are now confronted with this interesting new term `units' rather than `dollars'. I have been advised, by those who know, that one unit is $100.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Panizza quite correctly made a reference to the sentencing guidelines that judges take into account. What Senator Kernot said astonished me. I am puzzled why we need to have units instead of dollars. This is a serious matter and it will be interesting to see what advice we get. If the reason for having units instead of dollars is so that courts will have some discretion to convert the units into prison sentences as well as money, then I am going to run a campaign that is as good as yours, Senator Chamarette, to get this pernicious business of units taken out of legislation and to have dollars put back in.

That is for a reason, in terms of what I think is a very important relationship between parliaments and courts. I always understood that an important sentencing guideline, as well as the one Senator Panizza mentioned, was that judges are supposed to have some regard to what the legislators—in their wisdom or stupidity from time to time and who are elected by the people—think is a reasonable punishment or a reasonable provision in a piece of legislation. If the parliament in its wisdom or stupidity believes that a non-custodial sentence is appropriate and, indeed, by inference, that a custodial sentence is not appropriate—and I am prepared to be educated; that is why I find this a very interesting point; I have puzzled over this new term `unit', but not enough to lose sleep over it—if that means that judges can at their discretion send people to gaol—

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't mean that.

—It doesn't? You worried me, Senator Chamarette; that is what I am saying. I am about to be reassured, apparently. With the explanation that the minister will now give, you will probably support us, Senator Chamarette.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised by my legal advisers, having read the Crimes Act, that a penalty unit is a fine of $100. On the other hand, it is certainly the case that a reference to only a term of imprisonment does not prevent a court from applying a fine. But confusion may have arisen and therefore the need for clarification because we are talking about Commonwealth jurisdiction. There is variation in interpretation in states. That may clarify the position for you.
—Thank you, Minister; it does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —In the old days, when I was a youth—
—They really were the old days.

—Yes, they really were the old days. A specific figure, such as a fine for $100, used to be set and the magistrate or the judge could impose a fine of up to $100. But, because of the rage of inflation, the legislature could not keep up with the necessity of going through and changing $10 to $20 and what have you for every crime. So they started defining the penalties in terms of units.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of having to go right through every act to change the amount that a magistrate or a judge could fine a person for a particular crime, they started using units. So now you simply have to pass one bill that says, `From now on a unit is $100 or $200.' The whole system is kept up to date without going through the fairly onerous task of correcting every particular act. But I am interested in whether people can go to gaol in default of a fine. I would be interested to see what the provision says about that.

This is Senator Chamarette's last day, but two or three, and she ought to be praised. I would like to praise her on this issue of penalties. Imprisonment is too often used and there is a trend to use it more and more. That is a very bad trend. Imprisonment, by and large, does more harm than good to people. Of course there are other factors that have to be taken into account.

I think it has been said that parliament should take part in sentencing. Parliament should take part in sentencing, but only in so far as it sets maximums. Constitutionally, the task of sentencing people is up to judges and magistrates and that is where it should stay. Parliament should set only maximum penalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I apologise for adding a red herring to the debate. I thank the minister for clarifying the point. I have clarified with my office that in the past we have had that understanding, and I momentarily lost the plot of it.

BREAK.PARA: I do not think the argument, nevertheless, needs to be dismissed for that reason. It would be good to get the support on amendments 2, 5 and 6 with the recognition that we are throwing around imprisonment penalties. While I do not necessarily agree with fines as the ideal means, at some point we have to address the hard question of why we so readily imprison people or threaten them with imprisonment when we ought to be seeking other more preferable means that do not damage society as much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that that is now clarified. That is another issue, and I do not doubt your sincerity in that regard. But the penalty provisions were introduced by the previous government. Your proposed amendments are inconsistent. I am not sure where Senator Collins stands now, or whether he is supporting Senator Chamarette's amendments. He indicated previously that he might have been. Are you still—
—I am happy to explain them.

—That is all right. I just wondered what the position was. If you are, then they are inconsistent with the stance of the previous government. The government's amendments to the penalty provisions are consistent with similar provisions in other Commonwealth legislation. Further, section 4B(2) of the Commonwealth Crimes Act provides that a court may impose a pecuniary penalty on a person even if an offence is expressed, as I said previously, to allow for a term of imprisonment only. It would, therefore, seem that there needs to be consistency between treatment of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal persons who break the law.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise and I support what you say in relation to keeping Aboriginal people out of prison because of the added penalty that is arrived at, in a sense, by imprisonment. We all recognise that. That came out—I suppose it has been known for a long time—of the Aboriginal deaths in custody report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that it is not the same position. The reason for that is simple. It is a new team and new consideration is being given. Among other things, there is a new shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs—
—An enlightened one.

—Hold your judgment—I think so. But consideration was given to this and we are aware of it, Senator Herron. It is not something that is just happening. But I appreciate the fact that you have drawn it quite properly to my attention. We will be supporting, with the Democrats, Greens amendments 2, 5 and 6 but not amendments 3 and 4.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, again for the convenience of the chamber I have a number of questions which I intended to put here today to assist us all. It is not a huge list but the explanations might turn out to be huge. If I had these questions delivered to your office, could I get an undertaking from you that you will use your best endeavours—again they are legal questions—to get us an answer today if you can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, certainly. I will try.
—Fine; you will try. That is all I can ask for. I will not press these questions in that case, minister. Thank you.
—Certainly we will use our best endeavours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 15. Schedule 1, item 50, page 27 (line 25), at the end of the penalty, add "or 100 penalty units".
16. Schedule 1, item 52, page 28 (line 3), at the end of subsection (3), add "or 10 penalty units".
Amendments agreed to.
Schedule 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I do not want any misinterpretation about any lack of feeling in respect of this last amendment—quite the contrary. For obvious reasons we have canvassed this issue at length. It is that section of the government's proposals that relate to the chair. We will be opposing this provision for all of the reasons that have already been given.

—We have been talking about the TSRA. I want to know: is that anywhere defined and what does it stand for? I have had a look at page 151 of the act but it does not seem to me to be defined anywhere. I do not want the answer now, but at some stage we should find out where `TSRA' is defined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, you have just confirmed that your interest is in the legal aspects completely, utterly and only.
—Comprehensively.
—`Comprehensively' is the word Senator Collins has suggested. `TSRA' stands for the Torres Strait Regional Authority, and it is defined.
—I don't think it is defined anywhere.
—I am pretty certain it is but I will check with my legal advisers. I am told page 151 of the act.
—But it is not defined there.
—It is defined, but it was an amendment to the act and it is not in the volume that you are looking at. But it is defined. So have a win.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2 negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Herron) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL 1996CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 June, on motion by Senator Kemp:

BREAK.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, we are dealing with two bills—the Customs Amendment Bill 1996 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996—which are being debated together. The opposition supports the first bill, the Customs Amendment Bill 1996, but we oppose the second, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to foreshadow that at the conclusion of the debate on the second reading I will move a motion which, if carried, will require the second bill to be withdrawn and recast. I recognise that that is quite a drastic step, but we take it for an important reason, and that is that the government, by virtue of this bill, breaks a most solemn election promise and seeks to impose a goods and services tax by stealth.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that at the federal election the then opposition, in the person of the then shadow Treasurer and now Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, made a promise. That promise was: no new taxes. This bill unmistakably and unavoidably imposes new taxes, and it does so on consumers and industry inputs.

Both these bills deal with tariff concession orders. The situation under the current law is that when no producer in Australia produces a good, that good can be imported into the country without tariff if it obtains a tariff concession. Where there is negligible manufacture or production of a good in Australia, that good can still be imported because it is held not to compete unfairly with Australian production.

The first of these two bills is a bill that we produced when we were in government, that is, the Customs Amendment Bill. The origin of this bill was the innovation statement. The innovation statement was announced by the then Prime Minister in early December last year and was a major industry policy initiative by the previous government. It served a very valuable purpose in promoting Australian industrial production and, in particular, in finding a bridge between the creativeness of Australian scientists and their ability to commercialise their scientific ideas in Australia rather than seeing them go overseas and be commercialised by foreigners. Regretfully, it appears that the majority of the measures announced in the innovation statement by the former government to enable that to occur will now be set aside. That is not the debate here.

One of the measures that we announced in the innovation statement was to remove the provision in the customs tariff concession order system in which, if there is only an insignificant producer, the foreign good can come into Australia without a tariff having to be paid. The first of these bills, the Customs Amendment Bill, holds true to that view and removes the market test. It makes other consequential changes. As well, it tightens the project status under the bill to the extent of projects over $120 million and is a bill that was widely hailed at the time it was announced by industry. It is, of course, supported by the opposition. It is a sensible measure and one which I think improves the functioning of the act and does not unfairly expose Australian industry to foreign competition.

That brings me to the bill that we oppose, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. The `GST by Stealth Bill' would be its better name. This bill is an extraordinary thing. As I said in my introductory remarks, it breaks a solemn election undertaking that there would be no new taxes. This is the third time in the short history of this government that that promise—so soberly and purposefully delivered to the Australian electorate—is to be broken. This bill imposes a three per cent tariff on imports which do not attract duty now or which, because the first bill is passed, by virtue of the passage of the first bill, will not attract duty. That is to say, the cost of those goods imported into Australia in the hands of the importers will cost three per cent more.

If those importers are wholesale companies, then of course one expects they will pass on that cost in the final product and retailers, in turn, will also pass that cost on to consumers. No‐one imagines that it will not be passed on. Indeed, the wry and cynical view of many consumers is that those costs are passed on, usually with a few extra costs as well.

In this bill the government also proposes to impose a three per cent cost on goods imported directly that go to the consumer market, whether they pass through the hands of an Australian manufacturer as a component in a completed good, or whether they come in and go to the market directly. That three per cent will, of course, be directly passed on. It is idle for the government to pretend it will not. It is wrong for the government to say, `This is not a tax; it is a tariff.' The government knows that, but the government also knows that if it tells the truth on this subject then it will be convicted, in its own terms, of breaking its own election promises.

The three per cent on imports is, as I have said, an astonishing and amazing thing. Mr Simon Crean, my colleague in the other place, sought from the minister there a list of these consumer goods and met a blank wall. Senator Chris Schacht, my colleague in this place, put a question on notice which led to the minister, Mr Geoff Prosser, providing a list of goods that might fall into the definition of consumer goods; and he has now made that available. I understand, if it has not already been done, it will be provided as an answer to Senator Schacht's question by the minister handling this bill tonight, Senator Parer.

The advice from Mr Prosser is extraordinary. It does not say that there are 20 consumer items that will be taxed, nor 100, nor 500. There will be 23,000 consumer items which will be taxed under this provision as it now stands and Mr Prosser's advice to my colleague Senator Schacht contains a sample of 2,600 items that have been provided by the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two thousand, three hundred.
—You say 2,300. I read the letter to say this, in the fourth paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: The attachment contains a list of approximately 2,600 tariff concession orders and commercial tariff concession orders selected from the 23,000 tariff concession instruments in force on 23 June 1996 which might loosely be considered consumer goods.

I think you would have to say, on the minister's own advice, that you are not properly advised on this matter, Senator Parer. What is the nature of these items contained in the list? Are they items of any significance or are they not? Of course, the list varies. There are items of huge significance that are in daily household consumption and there are items of lesser significance in occasional consumption. But what it means is that across the board there will be a hike in costs to consumers on a range of, as we know it, 23,000 different items of three per cent.

Let me give the Senate an example of some of the matters contained in the advice from the minister, Mr Prosser. Jigsaws will be taxed by three per cent; children's safety and hygiene products will be taxed by that amount; heat‐resistant ovenware will be taxed by three per cent; basketball nets and Christmas stockings will be taxed by that amount; sporting footwear will be so taxed; babies' bottles will be taxed that way as well; hair accessories will be taxed that way; and if you are a musician, many musical instruments will be taxed, including percussion musical instruments and speaker systems. The list goes on; it is a long list. This is unquestionably and unarguably a GST by stealth.

The impact of these measures on Australian manufacturers will be to push up their costs and, where they supply the domestic market, they will pass those costs on—and that will add to inflation in this country. Where those Australian manufacturers import foreign components that would come in duty free, because of this bill they will have to pay an extra three per cent to import those components. So, if they sell their completed product on the international market, the cost to their customers in that market will reflect the three per cent that the imported component part of their finished good represents. That will also mean a higher cost for them.

These are matters of which consumers should be aware, and these are matters of grave concern to the opposition. For some time we have sought information on these items. It is gratifying that at last it has arrived, and in time for this debate.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, the opposition made a solemn election undertaking. Let me recite to the Senate the words of the now Treasurer, Mr Costello, at the National Press Club last year before the election when he gave the undertaking to which I refer:

But what I am saying here is, we'll not be hiking the income tax rates or company tax rates or sales tax rates or extending the sales tax in any way that the government is proposing. That is not our agenda. It is not our agenda to introduce new taxes. It is not our agenda to bulk up the currently existing taxes. That's not our agenda.
There cannot be any clearer expression of view than that.

This is the third breach by the government of that undertaking. The first breach occurred when it introduced legislation to wipe out the travel exemption provision for building workers in this country. It pretended that this meant that building workers would be treated the same as everyone else, when, of course, the occupation of a construction worker is different from every other occupation. Construction workers are required to start work at different locations depending on where their construction site is and, when they complete their work, to move to another location. For those reasons the exemption was preferred. Very few other workers are in a similar situation. But it is not for me now to argue the merits or otherwise of it because what nakedly is the case here is that a tax that did not exist before was imposed and that measure raises a new tax.

The second breach concerned the wholesale sales tax on motor vehicles. I will not canvass in this chamber again the debacle of the COAG meeting in which the state premiers rolled the Treasurer to a large extent. But senators will recall the debacle during the last two‐week break in Senate business and the final decision in which it was announced that $1 billion or more would be raised by pursuing the sales tax on motor vehicles. That caused the New South Wales government to say that its share of the cost was $900 million per annum or $100 per household and that it would seek to retrieve the costs that the Commonwealth had imposed on it by raising taxes.

In Queensland the cost is $190 million per annum and state taxes and charges will rise to compensate. In Victoria the cost is $600 million per annum. I think Premier Kennett has announced that he will keep the levy of $100 per annum on households in order to recoup that amount. In my own state of Western Australia the cost is $91 million. The state government says that it will absorb that amount by cutting out programs that exist and finding other efficiencies. It says that because there is an election in February in Western Australia and no government would hike taxes before an election. But if they are returned, you watch them. Taxes will go up and of that there is no doubt. So the second breach of the solemn undertaking concerns the outcome of the premiers conference and the impositions on the states which will cause the states to recover their position through taxes.

The third breach is this bill that we are considering this afternoon, the bill that ought properly be called `the GST consumption tax by stealth bill'—a tax on 23,000 items. No wonder that in briefings to my colleague Mr Crean, Customs officials have called this a tax bill. No wonder the National Farmers Federation call it a tax. It is not surprising that industry also refer to it as a tax.

The Senate will know that the High Court has in the past defined a tariff as a tax. The government pretends this is not a tax. As I said, Mr Costello knows that if he tells the truth on this he will be found out that he has broken a promise. But not all of his colleagues are so reticent about calling a spade a spade. One of his ministerial colleagues, the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Moore, on April 12 this year said that it was `totally correct' to say that the removal of tariff concession orders was an extra tax on business.

The revenue measure that this new tax is hoping to gain is $100 million per annum. I will not delay the Senate by reminding the government at great length of all the remarks they made about the so‐called l‐a‐w law guarantee of the former Prime Minister but if they believe one whit of what they said then, they ought to be absolutely embarrassed.

We also know that this pushes up inflation and that unions in a strong bargaining position will recover their position but workers in a poor bargaining position will not. They will have to bear the burden of the extra charges. Those on fixed incomes and pensions will not be able to recover their position, either. This is universally seen for what it is: a tax. It has been called dreadful policy by John Moore, the industry minister, in briefings to industry groups. On that he is right.

We will be moving the amendment to which I referred at the end of the second reading stage to ensure that we require the government to go back and re‐examine what it has done, to cast this so that the effect does not fall on the consumer and to do it in a way in which, if they possibly can—I cannot see how they can, but at least they ought to be made to try—they can honour the election undertakings they have given.

After the first 100 days of this government there appeared in many newspapers and periodicals an assessment of their achievement. The Australian Financial Review, the Friday before the 100 days expired, had a snapshot of the achievements of various ministers. Against the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr Moore, it said that his achievement was that he rolled the Treasurer, Mr Costello, in cabinet on this issue. The intention had been to impose five per cent on imported goods for industry. The achievement of Mr Moore was to ensure that that was three per cent on industry and three per cent on consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, your time has expired. I understand that you have circulated an amendment to the customs tariff bill. Is it your intention to move it now?
—It is now my intention to move my amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "That", substitute "the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 breaches the Government's election commitment that it would not increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes and should therefore be withdrawn, redrafted and re‐presented in a form in which:
(a) goods for personal consumption to which Tariff Concession Orders apply continue to enter Australia free of duty; and
(b) no change is made to the duty rate which currently applies to Policy By-Laws".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler, Sen Sid

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate tonight is debating two bills cognately, the Customs Amendment Bill 1996 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1996. The first bill is one that the Australian Democrats will support. It is designed to revamp and streamline the administration of the policy by‐law system and, generally, to reform the tariff concession system to ensure that Australian industries are protected and advanced in their efforts to maintain jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill seeks to remove the market test from the core criteria. It will leave substitutability as the sole criterion for determining whether a concession will be granted. Clearly, this will provide additional protection for Australian manufacturers by making it more difficult for importers to obtain concessions. In particular, it will remove the scope for importers to obtain the concession on the grounds that it will not significantly adversely affect Australian manufacturers.

The Democrats believe that it is important to remove this test because of the difficulty faced by Australian manufacturers in showing that markets for its goods will be adversely affected. The only core criterion that will thus remain is the substitutability test which will ensure that concessions will be available only where there is no domestic manufacturer of a substitutable good. We agree that the honours for demonstrating that there are no substitutable goods produced in Australia should rest with the prospective importer, not with manufacturers. This part of the bill will remove a considerable burden from industry. Overall, the Democrats believe that this bill introduces changes which, while tightening up the tariff concession system, enhance it and improve the assistance it provides to Australian manufacturers.

PARA.BREAK: I turn to the second bill, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1996. It is interesting to note that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr John Moore, said that it was dreadful policy. It was proposed by both the ALP and the coalition during the election campaign and very clearly was designed to raise revenue. But like so many other measures that this government is seeking to introduce in response to pressure from the Treas ury and finance departments, it bears little resemblance to a carefully constructed policy based on what effects the moves to gain revenue will have. It runs counter to many statements that have been made by industry leaders and also by authoritative bodies that have looked at the effectiveness of the tariff concession scheme. In a 1991 inquiry, the Industry Commission found:

SPEECH.PARA: No case for terminating a tariff concession system which alleviates taxes on production inputs and on other goods in a wide area of economic activity.
That report identified lower consumer prices and higher national income as the result of these tariff concessions.

The government backed down on the initial proposal to impose a five per cent tariff after a tremendous outcry by Australian industries along with Queensland and Western Australian government backbenchers. Thus, we have the present bill, which is a compromise that really satisfies no-one. The effect will be to apply in substance a three per cent tariff where previously there was none.

As has already been stated by Senator Cook, this is a breach of an election promise. Despite government claims to the contrary, a tariff is, in effect, a tax. The industry minister, the Hon. John Moore, has admitted this. It is a three per cent tax on both consumers and industry and therefore on jobs. Let us make no mistake: if we load additional costs on our manufacturers and industries, it will mean that they will be less competitive in domestic and international markets. Their market share and sales will drop. Jobs will disappear and unemployment will rise.

That is the net effect of this bill which the government has brought to this chamber. One wonders what the policy substance of the bill is. What considerations lead to a bill which will demonstrably mean the loss of Australian jobs? It is also a backdoor GST, as has already been said in this chamber. Ordinary household consumers will be hit by price rises to a large identified raft of imported goods. Some of the items which will be hit include television sets, microwaves, vacuum cleaners, children's toys, playground equipment and neonatal equipment.

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats believe that this very clearly is in breach of the government's promise not to introduce a new tax. The Democrats will therefore attempt to exclude this section. I understand that the ALP opposition is considering opposing this section of the bill. The Democrats are of a mind to support the opposition. However, we are also mindful of the government's need to raise revenue. We will therefore suggest to the government that—I have communicated this to the minister, the Hon. John Moore, this morning—if it wishes to separate luxury goods from necessity of life items in the list of consumer items, the Democrats would be quite prepared to accept the three per cent tax on luxury items.

It is very clear that the sole purpose of this bill is to raise budget savings. Very clearly, it is not good industry policy. I have already said this and I will say it again: to the Australian Democrats, that part of the bill which imposes a three per cent tax on components which go into Australian products for both domestic and international markets and on capital equipment which our industries have to buy is by far the worst part of this bill. It will very clearly and quite demonstrably cost Australian jobs. Once again, one needs to ask: what is the thinking behind this bill put by the government whereby, at a time when our unemployment is trending towards 10 per cent, it is happy to introduce a bill that will hamper our industries, make it harder for them to compete and make it necessary for them to reduce the labour force and throw people onto the scrap heap?

Australian manufacturing is already suffering. A survey undertaken this month by the Australian Business Chamber and the State Bank of Manufacturers in New South Wales found that for the sixth consecutive quarter the main indicators of production, sales, orders and profitability have weakened and that manufacturers have more than doubled the number of jobs they intend to shed over the next 12 months. Extrapolating the figures for New South Wales nationally, this suggests that overall job losses in manufacturing could be well over 12,000.

This bill will merely exacerbate the present situation and result in a further reduction in domestic manufacturing and an increase in unemployment. So much for the government's commitment to help small business. It will simply make life more difficult for many of them.

The government may well argue that this measure will not cause excessive pain to Australian industry and that a shift in the dollar has more impact on Australian industry than this change to the tariff concession system. But this simply ignores the fact that every percentage point of input costs matters and that, unlike changes in the value of the dollar, we do have control over whether we introduce this measure. This government is quite intentionally and deliberately introducing a measure that will harm industries and cost jobs.

The government is concerned to increase revenue. It is talking about the $8 billion black hole. We already know that the $8 billion black hole has been based on the extremely rubbery concept of economic growth forecasts, which have already been shown to improve, and that the $8 billion is no longer $8 billion. Be that as it may, the Democrats understand that the government wishes to increase revenue and reduce the deficit. It is a policy that we do not oppose. But we call on the government to give some thought as to where they cut and to consider the consequences of whichever cuts are imposed.

We believe that the government should not automatically follow the Treasury line. Indeed, I quote once again the industry minister, the Hon. John Moore, who himself has attacked this monopoly of advice which is coming from Finance and Treasury:
The conventional wisdom, the views propagated by those two departments, are virtually unquestioned.
I quote the Hon. John Moore:
I think it is very unhealthy that you just have this Treasury line. I am saying they are not always right.
Too right, they are not always right.

Only the other day, on 17 June, it was reported in the Australian Financial Review that the minister believes that the government's unilateral tariff reduction program may have progressed too quickly and been too far in advance on nearby countries. He said:
I think some of the past negotiations on APEC . . . have been a bit like the Dance of the Seven Veils, in which Australia has been getting them off and nobody else has.

That is certainly well and truly on record. Apart from New Zealand, Australia is the country that has been pursuing tariff cuts with the greatest alacrity. Our tariff bindings under the WTO agreement represent a commitment not to increase tariffs above certain levels, except by negotiation and with compensation for affected trading partners.

But, following the GATT Uruguay Round, Australia's commitments involved achieving an average tariff cut of 44 per cent relative to 1986-87, with an average final bound tariff of 10.9 per cent. However, the Australian government has announced a program of tariff reductions well in excess of that commitment involving a reduction in average tariffs of 70 per cent and a simple average tariff of 6.3 per cent in 1996-97.

If the government wants extra revenue, revenue that will not harm our industries, revenue that will not increase unemployment and not cost Australians jobs, the Australian Democrats are happy to give the government an out, to give the government an avenue where it can raise additional revenue. All it needs to do is to slow down the tariff cuts by 12 months and collect $700 million. It is very simple.

It is possible to do that well within the obligations that we have under WTO. It will not harm our industries; it will benefit our industries. It will give the government $700 million. We are prepared to move that amendment during the committee stage and we will challenge the government to accept it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
