DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Compliance Report on ILO Instruments Adopted in 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am speaking today to the compliance report on ILO instruments adopted in 1995. Most of the report is in French. There is a background and summary at the front of the terms of Australia's compliance. I think the part of the report that is in French mainly relates to the protocol and the document itself.

There are some interesting points in the report that we should take note of. A summary of the provisions of the new instruments are outlined, but Australia's position in this regard is perhaps the most interesting. There is recognition of the position of mining in Australia. In relation to safety and health in mines, it points out that the Commonwealth has no jurisdiction over the subject matter addressed by the convention and the recommendation. Point 18 in this report states:

Following a preliminary examination of law and practice, at least two States (Western Australia and South Australia) consider that there is compliance with the Convention. Legal confirmation of these opinions will be sought before these Governments formulate a view concerning ratification of the Convention.
There are two governments that consider that they comply with the convention, but that has to be checked. Point 19 in the report states:

Queensland currently has compliance difficulties, but is developing new legislation. The implementation of the coal mining legislation has been delayed, due to the possibility of changes resulting from the recommendations of the Mining Warden's Enquiry into the fatalities at Moura No 2 Mine in August 1994. Queensland should comply with the Convention once the new legislation is developed and brought into force.

One of the lessons learnt from the dreadful incident at Moura is that it was considered a right of the workers at Moura to have access to information about their own safety. That included access to information about whether or not their lives were in jeopardy and whether or not particular actions and particular safety regimes, or lack thereof, did, at any time, put their lives in jeopardy. I notice that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) is deep in discussion at the moment, but probably not about this issue.

The point we were trying to make most decisively in relation to the Griffin Venture is that it is vitally important and a basic right of workers to know whether the actions of the company they are employed by, especially if their place of employment is a floating petroleum platform off the coast of Australia, are placing their lives in jeopardy. I am very distressed to find that that has not been dealt with in relation to the Griffin Venture.

There are indications that the Australian Capital Territory does not think the convention is applicable to it. There are not a great many mines in the ACT. Other jurisdictions have identified compliance problems. The fact is that Western Australia and South Australia consider they comply, the ACT considers it is exempt, Queensland has some problems and the other states and territories have compliance problems. There is still a long way to go in terms of occupational health and safety in mines in Australia.

I hope that the work done in relation to this ILO convention will assist with that. We ought to remember when developing any new mining operation or with any commercial push for world competitive prices that we do not go down the track of putting any conditions which deal with basic workplace safety at risk.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL 1996CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler, Sen Sid

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption I was speaking about the offer that we are making to the government to get additional revenue, far in excess of that which they are seeking with this destructive bill. It will be destructive to employment and Australian industries. Before I return to that point, I wish to emphasise that, while the Democrats do not oppose the second reading amendment moved by the opposition, we will be moving an amendment to it adding our concerns about the damage the government's legislation would do to Australian industries and employment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that the government has another avenue to consider and I believe it should consider it carefully. Numerous industry groups have in fact called on the government to adopt such a policy. It seems that the government refuses to listen. Questioning tariff reductions remains taboo with the economic rationalists who seem to control the debate.

Ironically, in this particular case, the government is introducing a new tariff, but will not consider even temporarily pausing scheduled reductions in existing tariffs even though Australian industry has warned it that the measure is harmful—and that is very obvious—and that some relief in the tariff reduction program—which is not necessary and which is not matched by our trading partners—would improve Australia's economic position immeasurably. The general tariff rate is set to go down from about seven or eight per cent to five per cent on 1 July 1996. The tariff for the textile, clothing and footwear industry is set to go down by two to three per cent on 1 July 1996. The tariff for the motor vehicle industry is set to go down from 25 to 22.5 per cent on 1 January 1997.

As I have already said, these reductions are not necessary under our WTO obligations. One keeps wondering why the government is persisting in disadvantaging our industries, causing them to lose jobs, while our competitors, our trading partners, are protecting theirs.

The Democrats are not neo-protectionists, as we have so often been called in this chamber. We accept the need for tariff reductions. We accept the discipline that that imposes on our industries to become more competitive. But we do reject damaging our industries far in excess of what our tariff partners are doing. Why should we disadvantage our industries in their hard struggle to match the competitive behaviour of our trading partners? Why should we put our jobs at risk? Why should we destroy our jobs? This is the message that the Democrats are giving the government on this particular legislation, and I trust that the government will desist from pursuing this bill.

In fact, the suggestion was made that the bill should be referred by the government to the productivity council. It should be withdrawn from this chamber and provided to the productivity council to assess the damage that it will cause. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler, do you wish to move an amendment to the amendment?
—My amendment has not yet been circulated.
—We will look at the possibility of doing it by leave later on.
—Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) is designed primarily to increase the concessional tariff rate from zero per cent to three per cent, and for the Greens (WA) this is a somewhat vexatious issue. On one hand, a fairly purist or theoretical position, we see the establishment of concessional rates as working against the establishment of industries in Australia. If any good that is not produced in Australia—or where a similar good is not produced in Australia—is granted a total exemption from tariff, why should any producer wish to locate in Australia, aside from the fact that it is a beautiful country with a good climate and a remnant of a decent social system? Basically, there is no economic incentive to do so, unless the market is big enough to be attractive, and other factors such as proximity to that market, or length of transport lines, provide important competitive factors.

PARA.BREAK: The argument is that, if there is a tariff on these goods, it allows the development of industries in these areas. It allows new enterprises to somewhat lower the barriers to market entry. The Greens do not see such a measure as protective, but rather as a mecha nism to promote development. It is our assessment that in many cases where the market is big enough, or where there are other general factors, industry has no reason not to site here, particularly since by siting here it immediately ends the situation under which the concession is offered.

SPEECH.PARA: The people for whom it may be important are probably not the mass market suppliers, but rather the specialty market, technical market or niche market suppliers. These may not have a lot of start up capital, but some pre-existing advantage may assist them. They can go to the banks or potential customers with price advantages and try to get support for establishing an industry without having to establish it first, then having to go through measures to knock out the concession, and then trying to build their market.

For the largest suppliers, we would have to say that many of them would take advantage of the potential to eliminate the concession and create an advantage, but they do not do so because they have global marketing plans and siting in Australia is not included in them. It is not a purely economic decision—it is strategic decision—to site elsewhere and export tariff free to Australia. This begins to raise some of the `real ekonomic' considerations that create an `on the other hand' point of view.

The reality is that we live in a highly integrated global economy. Large economic interests map out overall international strategies and have considerable interlocking with other businesses who are either supplier companies or provide alternative markets. Many smaller high‐tech companies have contracts linking them with a few large corporations or conglomerate buyers, and are effectively satellite companies. For example, many of the new developments or niche products are made for IBM by independent small businesses, although they are highly dependent on IBM. In terms of global corporate strategy, Australia has not been chosen as a national site for development of high value added products, but is rather a producer of raw materials. What higher value industries have arisen here are usually the outcome of development of Australian‐owned small businesses. While there may be computer assembly businesses here, many components are controlled by a few big producers and made elsewhere.

In such a situation, the introduction of a three per cent tariff on goods not produced here is not likely to have much effect on investment patterns at all. Really, it is other factors in most cases that dictate whether companies locate here or not. Most of our high-tech businesses arose because they were started by Australians who wanted to continue to live in their own country. It was not the pre‐existence of a tariff that encouraged their investment here, although such a tariff may make the job of establishment a bit more easy.

If the existence or non-existence of a zero concessional tariff rate which would disappear if a company started up here does not make much difference to investment, what other effects does it have? One thing it does do is make inputs to industry a little cheaper. Where it does not damage development of Australian products and promotes imports, this is a good thing, whether the industry produces for export or the domestic market.

It is also said that it may make consumer costs less, though I think this is a bit more dubious. It could, if the differential is passed on to consumers rather than used to increase profit margins, but the relationship between costs of inputs to manufacturers, costs to distributors or wholesalers and the cost to final consumers is not clear cut. For inputs to a final product, it certainly would have the effect of reducing production costs.

In any case, when there are cost increases, sellers do not usually hesitate to pass them on, and a three per cent increase on the import price is not a major increase per unit. Obviously, a $100 import product would cost $103. If it were directly resold to a consumer at a 100 per cent mark‐up, the consumer would pay $203 rather than $200—though I could not guarantee that this is the way people mark up. This would probably not be large enough to change your decision to buy.

PARA.BREAK: Often the mark-up would be higher from import to retail sale. When the increase is on a capital good in manufacture and the in crease is distributed over the goods produced, the effect of the tariff on the price to the consumer ought, in most cases, to be negligible. The issue is mainly of concern for production inputs, where cost differences may be more critical.

SPEECH.PARA: The question then is whether the impact of raising production costs by increasing the tariff on goods when there is no comparable Australian product outweighs the impact of rises in market entry barriers. In that context, it is worth pointing out that over half the tariff concession usage is for capital equipment.

This is an evolving debate. A few days ago, all parties were apparently debating this internally. At this point, I indicate that the Greens support the opposition's second reading amendment. We believe that this is effectively a kind of consumption tax, generally referred to as a producer tax. In other words, it taxes the other end of the spectrum from retail sales taxes and at a stage prior to Australia's wholesale sales taxes. As such, it not only has the regressive attributes of a consumption tax, adding to the cost of goods to eventual consumers; it also has an adverse impact on exports. It does this, as the amendment says, without actually promoting the development of Australian industry. In fact, by negatively impacting on the cost of domestic production, it works against the development of Australian domestic and export industries.

We support the notion that this impost on production should be taken away. There are better and more progressive means of raising revenue. One such means, often put forward by the Greens, is the establishment of a lower limit—a minimum below which company taxes cannot be reduced. Company tax as we know is 36 per cent, yet many companies pay far less—often levels less than five per cent. I sometimes wonder whether some companies expect that the community ought to be paying them. We suggest at least a billion dollars is to be gained by setting the company tax level at 20 per cent and making it a level below which companies cannot further minimise their tax.

BREAK.PARA: There is also the issue of the loopholes identified by Treasury which are used by the top 80 or so taxpayers. It was foreshadowed that closing these loopholes would bring in over half a billion dollars annually. I suggest that these are areas for increasing revenue which should be used long before we create negative impacts on industry that will flow on in a regressive fashion to consumers.

What we have pointed out is not simple to explain, because we are not talking about a simple issue. That is why it is clear that there was obviously a lot of discussion within all parties involved. There was certainly the same kind of to‐and‐fro discussion within our own office when we talked through the issues and looked at the various case scenarios which we have dealt with. I do believe that in this case there is a necessity to go back to the drawing board and look at the basis upon which the legislation was drafted to see what it is hoping to achieve. I think that is really important.

If you are setting a tariff or a tax—but in particular a tariff—usually there is an industry basis to it. You would ask, `What are we hoping to achieve from this?' If it is just a revenue measure, you would not use a tariff. You use a tariff for a particular industry outcome, and you make sure that is what the tariff will achieve. In this case, I believe that what has been presented is not as clear as it should be. Therefore, it is misrepresenting itself as a tariff when it is, in fact, a form of consumption tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to say a few words about this government—the `no new tax' government with its big list of new tax items. There is a list of items to be taxed which has some 2,600 out of a possible 23,000 or more consumer items on it. It is clearly the case that this is a tax on consumers no matter which way you look at it. This is a move from a government that said it would not introduce a new tax—it made that commitment many times. The Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and all of the coalition members said in all of their promises and in all of their policy documents that there would be no new taxes. As other senators have said, this is a backdoor way of getting a consumption tax in.

SPEECH.PARA: The list of 2,600 items is very interesting. Why are there just 2,600? When it comes to balls, why is it that we have baseballs, softballs and T‐balls, but not golf balls, cricket balls, footballs and so on? What is the difference when it comes to differentiating one ball from another? Also, there are knives other than fishing knives. I am very interested in the fishing issue, and on the list is fly fishing reels that do not exceed a weight of 256 grams. What is the difference?

There is a whole host of questions that must be asked. We get to water dispensers. I think Senator Calvert said that the tax is only on luxury items. But our poor old pets cannot have water bowls that are designed to be mounted in cages for small pets. It is really quite a ridiculous situation.

More important is the fact that this government has also said that it is about creating employment, yet it now proposes to introduce a tax and change certain aspects of the current act. Some industries will suffer as a result of these changes—in particular, some industries in my state. One industry that will suffer is an industry which is just in the process of starting up. They will be hit with a tax when clearly they should not be.

This is about an employment oriented export industry. I would have thought that this government, given all of the things it has said in the past, would have been all for promoting these types of industries. Instead, what do they do? They put a three per cent tax on them—a tax that has some major implications.

I notice that Senators Gibson and Watson from Tasmania are now in the chamber. You ought to be very interested in this issue, because you know that our state is suffering very badly as a result of a lack of investment. Therefore, you ought to be ensuring that we are not burdened with further imposts that may deter potential investors and developments in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will fix it up. Wait until tomorrow.

—I am not going to wait until tomorrow, Senator Watson. I would have thought you would have been out there thumping the table and making sure that we do not end up with these sorts of things, but not a word has been said from you people.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing is the retrospective nature of this. I do not know how many times we have heard the now government when in opposition talk about retrospectivity and how unconscionable and terrible it was if there was ever any retrospective application of anything, let alone tax. Of course, what do we see with this piece of legislation? Retrospectivity—something that you people over there said was abhorrent and should never occur, yet you are planning to have it.

Firstly, you should not be introducing a consumer tax by the backdoor. Secondly, you should be adhering to the promises that you made to the Australian public about employment and making sure that industries and business can get on with employing without having the burden that you now plan to impose upon some of them. Thirdly, the retrospective aspects of what you are proposing just should not happen. Quite clearly, as my colleague Senator Cook has proposed, this bill should be withdrawn and reconsidered in another way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GIBSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I had the opportunity to read the Australian Stock Exchange's 1994 share ownership survey. It is the fourth of its kind since 1986. These surveys have been conducted as a means of gauging the extent of share ownership by individual Australians as opposed to share ownership by governments, corporates, institutions and overseas investors. The surveys include data about the characteristics of individual Australian shareholders.

SPEECH.PARA: Although time does not permit me tonight to elaborate on all the findings of the survey, there is one particular statistic that I would like to draw the Senate's attention to.The survey indicates that share ownership by tertiary graduates more than doubled during the years 1991 to 1994. However, over the same period share ownership by those who had not completed high school halved.

These statistics are another indication, if one were needed, of how those people in our community who are most vulnerable are the first affected by a government's inability to manage an economy. As you will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, the period 1991 to 1994 marked the trough of the economic maladministration of the former Labor government under Prime Minister Keating. It is now clear to all Australians that, while the former Labor government was desperately attempting to spend its way out of the quagmire of economic failure, many of the very people it said it was trying to help were in fact being made worse off by those very same efforts.

There is a lesson in this history for all governments, and there is a billboard size message in this history for all senators. The message I would suggest is this: before parliaments, governments or vested interests in the community seek to defend, isolate or protect the expenditure of taxpayers' funds, particularly by claiming that no program should ever be abolished or altered, they should be entirely sure that the expenditure in question not only is contributing in a positive way to the welfare of our society but also represents the best way of achieving the relevant goal. Some will say this is economic rationalism at its worst, that this is the thinking of bean counters. But, if seeking to get the maximum benefit for those in most need is a definition of economic rationalism, thank heavens for rational economists and may the beans be counted forever.

The National Commission of Audit report to the government released last week has been summarily dismissed by many, including many Labor and Democrat senators. I find such prejudices unfortunate and a derogation of responsibility to the Australian people. There are many recommendations of the audit commission report which I understand are unpalatable to many in our community. That this should be so is not surprising. The report uncovers many desperately disturbing trends in our society. If it can be said that the recommendations are extreme, it is only because the problems they address are extreme.

What is therefore surprising, indeed disturbing, is that certain senior politicians in this place and the other have been prepared to dismiss the recommendations without first considering the extent of the problems those recommendations seek to address. It is one matter for a sick patient to say to the doctor, `I do not like your medicine,' but it is an entirely different thing for the patient to say to the doctor, `I don't believe I'm sick,' even though the patient is crippled, run‐down, decaying and forecast to get worse as time goes by.

I believe that the Australian people will be well served when the full ramifications of the National Commission of Audit report are fully evaluated and analysed. While debate at present is focused on many of the severe remedies outlined by the commissioners, there has yet to be a reasoned and balanced assessment of many of the critical demographic, economic and social trends contained in the report. I urge all senators to read deep into this report, for, as always, the devil will be in the detail. In this instance the detail is the message of trends and directions of our nation. We, as the elected representatives of all Australians, have this obligation to our people. I hope hysteria and blind prejudice will not obscure this critical assessment.

Having briefly strayed from the matter of the stock market, I would like to now return to the theme I commenced with. The stock market is an entity much misunderstood. It is not the playground of the young, as some would say, any more than it is the refuge of the greedy. It is rather the interaction of many thousands of ordinary Australians, institutions and companies. All participate in the hope of advancing economic wellbeing; all take risks; all hope for a better future.

To help Australians understand their stock market, the Australian Stock Exchange, ASX, has taken a particularly committed attitude to educating Australians on the workings of the market. In this role of education, the ASX has developed a number of surprisingly innovative and instructive programs which target specific groups and individuals in our society. I would like to highlight two of these programs this evening.

An education program designed for senior secondary school students utilises a share market game which aims to provide students with a practical insight into the workings of the share market. The game is a computer simulation exercise based on the buying and selling of shares. At a national level, approximately 20,000 school students from 900 schools across the nation participate in this activity.

The ASX is also using the services of the Internet to provide access to this game. Internet access will be available at the beginning of 1997. Considering the estimation that 71 per cent of schools will have access to the Internet by 1997, the number of students with access to the game should increase substantially. The Stock Exchange is also in the process of developing a public version of the game, following its success in secondary schools. It seems that Monopoly will never be the same.

The second program I would like to mention this evening is perhaps one of the most enterprising education programs I have ever encountered and an example of a truly commercial entity in this community. Recently the ASX began a trial program to provide public lectures on trains. The pilot program was held in association with the Australian Commuter Education Services Department of the University of Western Sydney. A number of western Sydney evening trains were targeted for the exercise. Lectures on share investment were given to commuters while they were travelling home from work. The pilot course was supported by City Rail and attracted 26 participants.

There are many other programs I could bring to the Senate's attention. Public open days, Women's Investment Day, ethnic seminars and in-house lecture series in capital cities and regional and rural locations have all been developed by the ASX to bring the stock market into the homes of average Australians in a manner that makes the one-minute flash on the evening's news comprehensible to more and more Australians.

The operation of the market is often maligned by many of the senators of the Labor and the Australian Democrat parties. They find the market to be unjust and soulless. They consider it to be important to control market participants and to protect individuals from themselves. They may even go so far as to believe that governments have the capacity to judge what is really best for people. With the greatest of respect for all senators who hold these views, I have to say that you are wrong. The assumptions which underlie beliefs such as these are fallacious.

Given valid information it is the individual who is best placed to make those investment decisions, whether it is with or it is without professional advice. The information sessions conducted by the ASX can serve only to enhance the ability of individuals to make those decisions in a rational manner which will best serve their interests. Regulators and legislators have a major role to play in ensuring potential investors have sufficient access to information. However, we should make sure that we leave the decisions to the individual.

I commend the Stock Exchange on its 1994 survey and its educational and promotional activities. The initiatives undertaken in these areas by the ASX are innovative and could provide a blueprint for other organisations in this country. By investing in the Australian stock market, Australians encourage confidence in our free enterprise system and help to develop and sustain economic growth for today and for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —During the 1996 election campaign the now Prime Minister, John Howard, made himself as small a target as possible. In the United States one of the Clinton presidential campaign slogans was, `Change verses more of the same.' John Howard's slogan could have been, `More of the same' in 1996. He did not talk about his plans for Australia except in the broadest terms. He was relying on the `It's time' factor and his strategy was to keep his mouth shut and his head down.

SPEECH.PARA: That contrasts sharply with John Hewson's election style in 1993. At least John Hewson let the Australian people know what to expect if they got a coalition government. John Howard did not have the guts to go to the Australian people in March of this year with his plans for the country. He knew that if he shared his plans for Australia he would have been rejected, as John Hewson was rejected in 1993.

But, now that John Howard is in government, he is putting into effect his secret agenda. What we are seeing now is John Howard setting the scene for a reintroduction of the Fightback agenda. John Howard asked the Treasurer, Peter Costello, to start tilling the ground into which the Fightback seedlings will be planted. So the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) drew up the terms of reference for the National Commission of Audit.

They drew up terms of reference so that they could get the answers they wanted. They wanted someone to tell them that it is time to slash and burn the public sector, to get rid of 28,000 public servants; they wanted someone to tell them to introduce Medicare co-payments and cut pharmaceutical benefits; to means test the child-care cash rebate; to charge people for the care they need in nursing homes; to dump responsibility for health, education and welfare on the states; to withdraw from public housing, to line the pockets of landlords with rental subsidies but not to build decent public housing; to make university education as inaccessible as it was in the 1950s and 1960s, when John Howard was a student and when you needed well-off parents to be allowed to set foot inside the gates of a university. Every pensioner is now on notice. They wanted someone to tell them to end Labor's indexation of pensions and pensioners have no guarantees past this budget.

The first phase of the attack on the Australian people will be the August budget. It was foreshadowed yesterday in a document leaked from the Department of Social Security: cuts in family payments; attacks on the long-term unemployed; parenting payments to stop when a child reaches 12; slashing rental assistance—6½ billion dollars worth of cuts. If they are not the cuts, there will be other cuts. They have exposed the second phase of their attack this week in the National Commission of Audit, which is their long-term plan for an assault on our standard of living in this country. The National Commission of Audit report is the conservative's blueprint for their next term. It is wishful thinking for them, but if they were to be elected, that is the blueprint for the future for them.A coalition will not get another term because the Australian people will reject these destructive policies.

Significantly, Mr Costello did not ask the Commission of Audit to consider revenue raising measures. Could it be that he knew his mates in the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry could be relied on to keep up the pressure for a GST and give the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) the opportunity to do a somersault when, if there were a next term for this government, they could bring back the GST?

The GST is the third leg of the trifecta as far as the Liberal Party is concerned. The whole GST campaign is lovingly choreographed by the Australian Financial Review. Despite our denials, they have even reported that the left of the Labor Party supports the idea. The Australian Financial Review has some bizarre idea that the Business Council of Australia and ACOSS and the left of the Labor Party are going to work together to bring about a GST. That is how obsessed they are with piping their own line. Other journalists, unfortunately, are repeating this.

We in the left, like our colleagues at ACOSS, are concerned about fair and broadly based tax revenue collection. We are concerned that the burden of taxation is equitably spread. We abhor tax avoidance, but let me place on record once and for all that the left of the Australian Labor Party does not believe that a consumption tax is a fair and equitable way of raising tax revenue. Not one section of the left of the Labor Party in any state have come forward with a proposal for a GST. We do not support a consumption tax.
The burden of a consumption tax disproportionately falls on those families on low incomes, who spend a greater proportion of the family income in buying necessities.

Consumption taxes never remain at the level at which they are introduced. We have seen the evidence of other OECD countries. In Denmark, where a consumption tax was introduced at the rate of 10 per cent, the rate is now 25 per cent. In Britain it was originally 10 per cent; it is now 17½ per cent. Sweden went from 11.1 per cent to 25 per cent. On average the initial rate of introduction of a consumption tax is 12.6 per cent and the average rate after a few years is 17.1 per cent.

The usual reason for pushing the consumption tax line is that consumption taxes minimise tax avoidance. Let us minimise tax avoidance by all means but, for my part, let us look at the people who can afford to contribute more in this country. Mike Steketee had a whole list of areas we could tighten up in an article in last week's Australian: dividend imputation, tax breaks for infrastructure bonds—that has been debated this week—and negative gearing. Let us look at those 80 people with assets of over $30 million each who have reported taxable incomes of less than $20,000 a year. Some of these people are claiming Austudy for their children. That is the sort of obscenity that we have in this community at present. Let us start with Australia's top 100 tax avoiders, whose names the department already has.

So as far as I am concerned the Labor Party has a united position of opposition to the main thrust of the National Commission of Audit. Of course there are positive things; I am not denying that. But the main thrust of the proposals is definitely from the extreme economic rationalist viewpoint and clearly reflects that agenda. We have even had the Liberal Party leadership so embarrassed by the proposals being so extreme that they are trying to move away from them. It is significant when we turn to the issue of the GST that the very last piece of legislation considered in this chamber just a few minutes ago, the customs tariff legislation, was a consumption tax where this government, because of their business friends and the pressure from them, moved to thrusting the tax burden onto ordinary people—a classic example of the priorities of this government. When business interests moved on them, they jumped.

I believe that everybody in the Labor Party, as our leader has made clear, is opposed to a consumption tax. The left of the Labor Party, the right, the centre and the independent people in the Labor Party all support the position that we have put in two elections opposing it. I just wish that the people who represent business, the Business Council and the business interests that are associated with this push for a consumption tax, would keep the debate to their own people because we on this side of the chamber reject their view.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Child LabourGun ShowsVictoria: Regional Business Facilitators

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler, Sen Sid

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to address three topics briefly. The first relates to the report of the Tripartite Working Party on Labour Standards, which I will be seeking to table later. Secondly, I will be referring to a collection of documents which show the infiltration of right‐wing elements in gun shows and expositions, and in the organisations of genuine shooters. I will be seeking to table those documents also. They have been cleared with the portfolio holders and the whips to ensure that there is no difficulty with having them tabled. Thirdly, I will advert to the Victorian government's sacking of 21 regional business facilitators. I am not sure whether that sacking has already happened or whether it is to be implemented soon, but it is something of great concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tripartite Working Party on Labour Standards was established in response to a motion of mine which the Senate passed unanimously some 18 months ago. That resolution called on the government to take action on the issue of exploitation of children in child labour situations.

The tripartite working party has worked assiduously for more than 12 months under the chairmanship of a former Attorney‐General, the Hon. Michael Duffy, and has produced a report which, I believe, needs to be seriously considered by this government. The recommendations of the report call on the government to take action against core labour standards—which is code for forced labour, child labour and other labour conditions—and to give priority to occurrences in our region.

BREAK.PARA: The report says that we should and must incorporate issues of social importance, with particular reference to child labour, into our trade negotiations. It suggests that Australian government representatives and our financial institutions should build those issues into the programs and funding that they provide to other countries.

The recommendations follow reasonably closely the submission that I made to the tripartite working party. I put forward the view that simply prohibiting the importation of goods made by child labour will not fix the problem; we must address the abject poverty of families in many Third World developing countries, who are virtually compelled either to exploit their children in their own backyards or to sell them into bondage.

I proposed that the AusAID agency concerned with overseas aid expenditure allocate a small amount to a pilot project providing primary school facilities in those areas where child labour is rife. I also proposed the expenditure of some money to generate work and income opportunities for parents. The report suggested expenditure of $15 million per annum over four years. I was more modest in my submission, asking for $20 million for the pilot program.

I have had some discussions on this matter with the Minister for Trade, Mr Tim Fischer. I said that while I recognised that the government is concerned that labour conditions per se are the concern of the ILO and is therefore reluctant to move on these recommendations, surely there is some obligation on civilised nations like Australia to take some note of child labour and the 20 million children estimated to be subjected to extreme exploitation in our region. I said that the government should consider taking some specific action in that area.
The report will now be available from the table office. I recommend that people interested in this issue obtain a copy. I seek leave to table this report.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second collection of documents that I wish to address briefly was provided by a constituent of mine who belongs to the Gun Control Group. The documents suggest that at gun shows and gun expositions held annually in Melbourne there is on display, unfortunately, some quite obnoxious material, including swastikas and other nazi insignia, and literature from right‐wing organisations, such as the Australian League of Rights and the Australians' Right to Bear Arms Association.

BREAK.PARA: Also, at some of these exhibitions, old and banned copies of the magazine Lock, Stock and Barrel were available. Having been the target of quite sleazy and obscene attacks from that particular publication, and from leaflets distributed in several Melbourne suburbs, I appreciate the concerns of this constituent.

These gun shows and expositions are not generally open to the public, and certainly not to the media, and it is, I understand, fairly difficult to access them. However, some people obviously were able to do that—have taken photographs, picked up leaflets and have placed this before us. I believe it is a matter of public interest to consider that and to suggest to shooters and shooter organisations who are genuine sports people and genuine hunters that they should ensure that these people do not infiltrate their organisations and do not use the occasions where guns are being sold for the propagation of extremist right‐wing propaganda which, surely in our society, we should avoid. I seek leave to table this set of documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final item that I wish to briefly advert to is an article by Peter Hunt in the newspaper Weekly Times of 12 June. It states:

BREAK.PARA: Victoria's rural townships have been hit by a state government move to sack 21 regional business facilitators.

That is in the face of an independent study of the decline in services to rural communities, which was commissioned by the Anglican Church and which found that each facilitator assisted in developing at least 20 new suitable business ventures each year. The report's author, consultant Kate Hely, spent six months last year talking to 17 community organisations and 133 individuals in the Mallee, the Goulburn Valley and the Western and Central Districts. It is not just a trumped up report. It really does show the value of regional business facilitators.

It is also relevant to what is being done at Commonwealth levels. I draw the attention of senators to the so-called REDOs, the regional economic development organisations, which were established by the previous government and which, I hope, will be continued by this government. I wonder what this government will say to this move by a state government to withdraw its people and throw the whole load onto the Commonwealth government.

There was one particular community in Donald, in western Victoria, where I had occasion to meet Mr Graham Harris, the regional business facilitator of the program. The article mentions him and some enterprises. The Donald Fairmark shirt factory is mentioned. The manager, Beryl Milham, whom I have met, said that her facilitator, Graham Harris, had been a driving force behind establishing the factory. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in great sadness tonight to speak of Jack Boardman. Jack Boardman was a longstanding acquaintance of mine. He was a man I greatly admired. It is not true to say that we always agreed but, if we did not agree, I must say that I was always forced to acknowledge the overwhelming compassion he expressed and the absolute sincerity of the views that he held.

SPEECH.PARA: John Gorey Boardman died last Thursday, 20 June 1996, aged 77. He died from injuries sustained after being hit by a car on Monday night whilst on his way to attend a meeting of the Friends of East Timor. A long‐time member of the Labor Party, Jack Boardman and his wife Beryl were recognised in December 1993 with Outstanding Service Awards. With Beryl, he had a lifetime commitment to the socialist and pacifist movements.

He was a member of the ALP from at least the 1960s, and possibly earlier. He was a member of the Scarborough Karrinyup branch of the ALP, holding most positions in the branch over the years as well as being a delegate to the Stirling electorate council and to the state executive.

Jack and Beryl worked tirelessly on every election campaign anyone could remember, often to the point where concern was felt for their physical wellbeing. Indeed, in the 1996 campaign, Jack was given a reasonably small area to letterbox in deference to his age, but he always beat the rest of us by taking on at least two other areas to do as well.

He was a quiet and caring man of great compassion who put his views in a quiet and most dignified manner, even though they were often at variance with the prevailing view within the party. He was quite fearless in expressing his views, to the great annoyance and inconvenience of some and to the great admiration of others. Jack and Beryl's contributions to party debates on matters as diverse as Aboriginal affairs, the environment, social justice and foreign relations have been immense, impressive and generally well ahead of their time. Jack was a committed socialist and pacifist even during World War II, when he served with great distinction in the Air Warning Wireless Company in New Guinea, commonly known as the Coastwatchers, and later in the Z Forces in Singapore and the 2/8 Australian Commando Squadron in Bougainville. He joined the Commandos in Lae in 1942 and fought in the Bougainville campaign right until the end of the war. He was very highly regarded by his comrades at arms in the Commandos as a man of great courage and immense forbearance. As one of his comrades said, `If Jack was on your patrol, you knew your patrol had an edge.' He was also a man of great tolerance and understanding, who was always there for his comrades with an ear to listen and a shoulder to lean on in their moments of great trauma.

The Commandos operated almost exclusively behind enemy lines to harass, ambush and sabotage, make maps and take prisoners. They were the elite unit of the army at the time. That a man who had served his country with such distinction held the views he did, particularly regarding pacifism, strengthened his case immeasurably in the eyes of many of those he dealt with.

BREAK.PARA: Jack was involved in many other organisations for the betterment of mankind as well. He was a long-time campaigner for Aboriginal land rights and the Aboriginal cause generally, most recently in the Swan Brewery dispute in Perth, and was frequently seen there early in the mornings, often in his old, yellow raincoat in the most atrocious weather.

Jack was a member of the United Nations Association from 1949 and he and Beryl gave countless hundreds of hours of volunteer service to it in the ensuing years. I mentioned briefly his support for the campaign to free East Timor. He participated in the voyage to Dili harbour of the Lusitano Express in March 1992 which was forced to abandon its mission by the Indonesian navy. Jack was a constant campaigner to free East Timor. This is but one example of his commitment.

He also participated in many environment and conservation campaigns, including the building of high‐rise developments on the Scarborough beachfront and the construction of a major road through the Trigg bushland reserve.

His infectious enthusiasm and wonderment at his environment will be greatly missed by all who knew him. No more will we hear his warm and sincere expressions: `Is that right?', `Wonderful!', `Well, isn't that marvellous?'

Mr President, I know you knew Jack Boardman too, and I would like to say: so long, Jack. I extend my sincere condolences to his wife Beryl and his three sons—Warwick, Ralph and Trevor and their families, including five grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to the increasingly responsible role and tasks undertaken by trustees of all the superannuation funds in Australia. The total retirement savings of all Australians has recently been estimated at $240 billion. This is predicted to grow to $2,000 billion by the year 2020. There are about 115,000 superannuation funds in Australia, of which 110,000 are small private funds with less than five members. These small funds are called the mums and dads schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Insurance and Superannuation Commission estimates that some 180,000 trustees of those funds are so small that they are excluded from a lot of the detailed compliance requirements under the SIS legislation—about 25,000 trustees of the remaining 5,000 funds. However, the industry is dominated by a small number of very large funds; the top one per cent account for more than 83 per cent of all superannuation fund assets, and 97 per cent of members.

Trustees are controlling increasing proportions of our national wealth, and their decisions can have a far‐reaching impact on investment in Australia. Superannuation funds control 25 per cent of equities listed on the Australian Stock Exchange, and a six‐fold increase is predicted over the decade of the 1990s. The import of the decisions made by the trustees of these funds on resource and infrastructure developments in our country, for example, is enormous.

I wish to take this opportunity of referring to some research undertaken by Dr Oldsberg, an economic sociologist and Director of the Australian Institute of Superannuation Trustees. Dr Oldsberg has just completed a major research of trustees' duties, responsibilities and levels of expertise.

Using a sample of 550 trustees representing a cross‐section of various types of funds, she has found that: trustees are generally young; 40 per cent are under 40, mostly male; only 13 per cent are women and are usually a trustee of just one fund—about 75 per cent; trustees are extremely committed to their task—and that is the issue I want to emphasise tonight—and trustees are either nominated and appointed or elected to their board positions. The vast majority of them are not paid, and perform their duties in an honorary capacity. Rarely are trustees relieved of other duties to attend to their trustee responsibilities. The duties and responsibilities of these trustees are increasing. Their liabilities under the new Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act are becoming more onerous and there is mounting concern among some trustees about the difficulties of meeting this challenge—but I think they are rising to the occasion very well.

She also found that trustees are working hard to develop their expertise to meet the challenges of growing and increasingly complex funds. The vast majority of trustees have done some specialised trustee education and training. Sixty per cent of trustee boards have a special allocation for trustee education and training.

The Australian Institute of Superannuation Trustees research reveals that despite the complexities of superannuation and the new demands of managing the funds, the trustees have an exceptional level of commitment and confidence in being a trustee. They have a personal commitment both to ensure that the funds perform as well as possible and thereby enhance members' retirement benefits and to safeguard members' retirement savings.

Trustees must be ever conscious of their responsibilities. They have not only a corporate but, unlike company directors, a personal responsibility. If they manage their funds prudently in accordance with the requirements of the SIS Act, they will have gone a long way to ensuring that the risk of fraud in their fund has been minimised and they will have discharged their responsibilities according to the act.

But a system whereby there is continual monitoring of funds and constant challenging of the effectiveness of the funds' controls and procedures is essential. They need to operate according to risk management procedures, maintain effective control and supervise vulnerable areas very closely. The responsibility for detecting and preventing frauds rests solely with trustees. They cannot delegate that responsibility, but they can take expert advice. For example, where an external administrator has been appointed, trustees must have foolproof assurance that this responsibility can be carried out within the context of the fund's internal controls.

PARA.BREAK: Dr Oldsberg's research has found that, as the funds grow larger and member accounts become more substantial, trustees are beginning to adopt a more pro‐active approach. They are moving from being fund administra tors to becoming active fund managers. They are now more actively searching for investments which will provide the greatest rate of growth for fund members commensurate with prudential safeguards. They are increasingly choosing equity ownership of Australian companies. They channel about 40 per cent of their assets into local equities. These investments will continue to have an enormous benefit in fostering the growth, development and efficiency of our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an increasing interest in issues of board structures and governance, remuneration and performance of company senior management, the relationship of executive and independent directors on boards. But, as the Trustee of the Year, Ross Greenwood says, the trustee's role is easy while the fund is growing. However, where there is a contraction of funds, some trustees around may be ill‐equipped to handle these situations. In this context training is absolutely essential. In this context the Australian Institute of Superannuation Trustees is setting up a national program of performance based training workshops for trustees, and I commend them on this particular initiative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 30 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Secretary of the department, Dr Allan Hawke, write to the Chief Executive Officer of Airservices Australia, Mr Bill Pollard, urging Mr Pollard to invite Mr Dick Smith to provide an airspace design proposal to Airservices Australia; if so, what resources have been placed at Mr Smith's disposal and what arrangements have been made to remunerate Mr Smith for this work and any expenses he might occur.
(2) Did Dr Hawke advise Mr Pollard that if he did not comply with this request the Minister would issue a directive to that effect.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. At Mr Pollard's invitation, Mr Smith is working with Air Traffic Control staff, consultants, aviation experts and industry. Airservices Australia is assisting him with the allocation of human and fiscal resources. No remuneration will be provided to Mr Smith.
